text: It might be a little early in the season to bill this match as a crucial relegation encounter but in the battle for survival in the Premier League every point must be fought for. Wolves stayed up by a single point last season. They have recruited Roger Johnson from relegated Birmingham and brought back last season's Tottenham loanee, Jamie O'Hara, on a permanent deal. Such reinforcements may prove crucial against a Blackburn side that could be shorn of both of its first-choice central defenders through injury. Rich Flower

Having finished a point apart last season, these sides have undergone transitional summers. Martin Jol will include Bobby Zamora, who sustained a broken hand in the Europa League a fortnight ago, for his first league match in charge of Fulham, though Zamora will wear a cast. Yet Cameron Jerome will not partner him in attack after Fulham refused to improve on their £3m midweek offer for the Birmingham striker. For Villa fans outraged at the appointment of Alex McLeish and dismayed at the loss of Stewart Downing and Ashley Young, debuts for Charles N'Zogbia and Shay Given will provide some cheer. Jonny Weeks

Liverpool have lost an opening-day home fixture only twice since 1962, and having spent £54m since bidding farewell to the most topsy-turvy season on record there is justifiable expectation on Kenny Dalglish's team to gain early momentum against this summer's other reconstruction work. Both sides need time to settle but, with 10 additions to a squad that underwhelmed last season, Steve Bruce's task appears harder. Sunderland's swollen ex-Manchester United contingent and Jordan Henderson provide the subplots but the midfield contest between Blackpool old boys Charlie Adam and David Vaughan should not be overlooked. Andy Hunter

Arsène Wenger's mood, hardly mellowed by painfully slow goodbyes from Cesc Fábregas and Samir Nasri, has been further darkened by logistical disruptions. When the Arsenal manager discovered his team's intended hotel on Tyneside was hosting a Geordie wedding party he switched the booking to a less conveniently situated property in Durham City. While Wenger wonders whether Alan Pardew will select Joey Barton, Cheik Tioté dreams of emulating his wonder volley which earned Newcastle a 4-4 draw after being 4-0 down in last season's equivalent fixture. Much may hinge on Yohan Cabaye's input in Pardew's midfield. Louise Taylor

If QPR are to stay up they will need to win home games against mainstream Premier League opposition of this sort on a regular basis. Bolton won only two away league fixtures last season and with Tuncay Sanli's attacking talents awaiting a work permit will be hoping that the arrival of Nigel Reo-Coker stiffens their midfield. Neil Warnock will look to Danny Gabbidon and Kieron Dyer to provide some wrinkles at the higher level while hoping his defence maintains last season's discipline and organisation. The attacking qualities of both teams should produce an entertaining fixture. David Lacey

As the Premier League enters its 20th campaign, it is easy to forget Norwich, top in early April 1993, could have been its inaugural champions. After competing in only one of its last 16 campaigns the Canaries have returned with a flourish, courtesy of back-to-back promotions. Manager Paul Lambert has been busy and must decide which of his new signings merit debuts on Saturday while Wigan's Roberto Martínez, another former Motherwell midfielder, may be without James McCarthy. But for Hugo Rodallega's winner at Stoke in May, these two clubs could have traded places over the summer. Richard Jolly

A team facing a period of transition cannot have wished for a trip to the Britannia Stadium in the first weekend of the season. The visitors take on last season's FA Cup finalists and the new Chelsea manager, Andre Villas-Boas, faces a particularly British sort of occasion. The larger issue for the visitors is the further regeneration of an ageing squad that is starting to creak a little. Stoke, for their part, are ready and settled – Tony Pulis's team beat Hajduk Split 1-0 both home and away in the Europa League qualifiers. Kevin McCarra

Manchester United's title defence begins at The Hawthorns, one of only five away grounds where they won in the Premier League last season. Lady luck was smiling on them on that occasion. Gary Neville should have been sent off and Peter Odemwingie missed a penalty for Albion. Despite United's impressive comeback against Manchester City last Sunday, which was inspired by younger legs, Sir Alex Ferguson is likely to put his faith in an experienced line-up here. Albion may give a debut to new signing Shane Long, with Odemwingie struggling to be fit. Stuart James

This represents a daunting start for Swansea in their first Premier League season, even though Roberto Mancini says neither Sergio Agüero nor Carlos Tevez will be fit enough to start. The Welsh team kept 21 clean sheets in the Championship last season and will need that defensive solidity against a side that, once again, has had considerable investment over the summer, with £50m spent and counting. Swansea's own recruitment has been altogether more modest, with Danny Graham their most expensive signing at £3.5m, and it is difficult to imagine they sympathise too much with Mancini when it comes to his complaints about the FA Cup winners not signing enough players. Daniel Taylor

Kenny Dalglish's Liverpool provided one of the horror moments of last season for Arsenal when they equalised in the 102nd minute at the Emirates, and they might not get a better chance to inflict more pain. Arsène Wenger is under siege, with his problems taking in a clutch of injuries and suspensions, Samir Nasri, and the difficulties in making signings. With confidence fragile, it is a time for stout hearts. Liverpool, flat in the second half against Sunderland, also operate under extremes of pressure but it feels as if Arsenal have more to lose. David Hytner

Alex McLeish's first home game as Aston Villa manager should be an ideal opportunity to also pick up his first win. Blackburn lost 2-1 at home against Wolves last weekend and have the look of a team that could be in for long season. Steve Kean hopes to give a debut to Radosav Petrovic, the Serbia midfielder who joined from Partizan Belgrade earlier this month, and should also welcome back experienced defenders Ryan Nelsen and Christopher Samba. McLeish has a full-strength squad to pick from with the exception of Carlos Cuéllar. Stuart James

The focus has switched firmly towards squad strengthening at Stamford Bridge as the transfer deadline approaches, though Chelsea's current crop must slip seamlessly into winning ways to inject momentum into their early season title challenge. André Villas-Boas' first home game in charge offers an opportunity – the Baggies, then under the current Chelsea assistant manager Roberto Di Matteo, were defeated 6-0 in south-west London last term – which cannot be passed up. Roy Hodgson's team, with Peter Odemwingie secured on new terms but still unfit, are much improved these days but still face an awkward afternoon. Dominic Fifield

Of all the football joints, in all the towns, in all the world, Queens Park Rangers would have to walk into Bill Kenwright's. Having detailed the club's financial problems and his desperate, fruitless search for new investment, albeit unwittingly, the Everton chairman welcomes a club who spent the past 15 years outside the Premier League yet have still attracted four wealthy owners recently – Bernie Ecclestone, Flavio Briatore, Lakshmi Mittal and now Tony Fernandes. One pertinent point about the game remains, however – no one at Everton would exchange David Moyes' squad for Neil Warnock's. Andy Hunter

Two clubs, two managers, two very different outlooks. "I don't look forward to any games now, to be honest. It's hard," says Steve Bruce. "I have a great job, the best in the world – until Saturday afternoon comes along." Alan Pardew disagrees. "I quite enjoy the games," he counters. "It's the Monday to Friday bit, the putting out of fires, I don't like. It's a genuine relief to be beside the pitch." On it, expect to see Lee Cattermole and Joey Barton wind each other up and opposing strikers Asamoah Gyan and Shola Ameobi vie for hero status. Louise Taylor

Swansea never expected to beat Manchester City, but Wigan at home is the sort of fixture from which they need maximum points if they are to stay up. Off the pitch, Brendan Rodgers is calling for a warm welcome for the former Swans manager Roberto Martínez. On it, he is looking for the return of captain Garry Monk and left-back Neil Taylor to stabilise a defence that shipped four on Monday. Wigan are unsure about the fitness of Steve Gohouri, Hugo Rodallega and James McCarthy, but Antolin Alcaraz is in line to return. Joe Lovejoy

Each club had sweeping victories in their opening fixtures in the Premier League. That seems to promise an exciting yet close contest, but it will be interesting to see whether Manchester City continue in so expansive a manner – Roberto Mancini will certainly appreciate that Bolton are very different opponents from the fragile Swansea side his team thumped 4-0 on Monday night. He also has to decide how much involvement there is for the £38m Argentinian, Sergio Agüero, a devastating substitute against the Welsh club. Kevin McCarra

Opening-day draws for Norwich at Wigan and for Stoke at home to Chelsea may not have entirely displeased either of these clubs, but given Stoke's poor away record last season, the Canaries will fancy their chances of taking all three points at Carrow Road. Imagine for a moment, however, that Tony Pulis does manage to sort out Stoke's away form this season – a top-10 finish would be the least of their ambitions. An injury to centre-half Zak Whitbread means the former Liverpool defender Daniel Ayala, for whom Norwich paid £800,000 this week, could make his debut. Richard Rae

Wolves fans should not get too excited – after an opening-day win over Stoke last season, they languished in 19th place in early October. A season-long fight against relegation was eased dramatically only on the last day of the campaign, when events elsewhere conspired in their favour despite a 3-2 defeat by Blackburn. It was Rovers who they beat 2-1 at Ewood Park last weekend. Battle-hardened Fulham have already completed the best part of 25% of a Premier League season, with seven of their eight matches in the tortuous Europa League qualification process that started in June. In that octet of fixtures, they have conceded just one goal. Russell Kempson

The loss of two experienced centre-backs would be a blow to most clubs but the absence through injury of Nemanja Vidic and Rio Ferdinand should provide a good opportunity for Phil Jones, Manchester United's summer signing from Blackburn. Despite the challenge ahead, Tottenham will at least feel rested after a 5-0 amble against Hearts in the Europa League on Thursday. It remains to be seen whether Luka Modric, if fit after injury, will take part, considering the speculation about a possible move to Chelsea. Kevin McCarra

This West Midlands derby brings together two teams that start the day in the top four. Wolves head to Villa Park, where they won last season for the first time in 31 years, in buoyant mood after picking up maximum points from their first two matches. Mick McCarthy is set to name an unchanged side against an Aston Villa team that will be forced to make a change at right-back. Eric Lichaj or Chris Herd will step in for Luke Young, who has a knee injury and is also in talks with QPR about a possible transfer to Loftus Road. Stuart James

Two teams who recorded the same result in midweek, with 3-1 home wins over the respective halves of Sheffield in the Carling Cup, are also united by 100% losing records – albeit from one game in Everton's case – in the league. Something has to give. The difference between Blackburn and Everton lies in the transfer market where David Moyes is unable to act and Steve Kean is frantically busy. Montenegro winger Simon Vukcevic and Brazilian full-back Bruno Ribeiro could both debut on the Sydney-bound Brett Emerton's Ewood Park farewell. Richard Jolly

Few give Norwich – without the defender Daniel Ayala for at least two months with a knee injury – any hope at Stamford Bridge. "It is our job to try and cause an upset," said the manager, Paul Lambert. With centre-back Elliott Ward out with a knee problem, the injury to the Spaniard Ayala was a tough blow. For Chelsea Alex could be replaced in central defence by the fit-again Branislav Ivanovic. The game comes too soon for David Luiz, who will complete his recovery from a thigh injury on international duty with Brazil next week. Rich Flower

Doing the double over Bolton was one of the few highlights of Roy Hodgson's brief, tortuous time at Anfield, although successive Liverpool managers have rarely been troubled by the Trotters. Bolton have lost their last nine matches to Liverpool and you would have to go back to 1954 to find their last league victory at Anfield. Both sides are suffering the after-effects of midweek Carling Cup wins. Kenny Dalglish will be without Raul Meireles, who suffered a collarbone injury at Exeter, while Owen Coyle saw Marcos Alonso join Bolton's growing casualty list with a fractured metatarsal. Tim Rich

Both teams are in need of a good result after embarrassment in midweek. Scoring goals has been a mutual problem, each having managed just one in their first three games, and their records are identical – one point apiece in the league and defeat against lower-division opponents in the Carling Cup. Swansea, seeking their first win since promotion, are again without captain Garry Monk, and are expected to be unchanged from their 0-0 draw at home to Wigan last week. Sunderland have John O'Shea fit to debut at right-back, with Phil Bardsley switching to the left in place of Kieran Richardson. Frazier Campbell is again absent, injured. Joe Lovejoy

Wigan complete their hat-trick of opening games against the promoted teams hoping to go one better than the two draws they have recorded so far. Roberto Mártinez will be aware that QPR at home, despite taking three points away from Everton, is a match his side must win if the club is to avoid being caught up at the bottom of the table early in the season. Neil Warnock's squad now has a leader in midfield in the shape of Joey Barton, but it is likely QPR will look to Adel Taarabt's craft to open up the Wigan defence. Gregg Roughley

Arsenal did well to overcome Udinese in the Champions League qualifier, but this challenge is likely to expose the limitations of a squad still desperately in need of new players. Doubts over the fitness of Thomas Vermaelen and Laurent Koscielny are also a grave concern, with no experienced alternatives available. United have won six of their last seven meetings with Arsenal at Old Trafford in all competitions, conceding just two goals, and were rampant in the second half against Tottenham on Monday night. Kevin McCarra

When Martin Jol resigned as Ajax manager on the day, last December, that Newcastle sacked Chris Hughton, the easy assumption was that the Dutchman was Tyneside bound. Not for the first time, two and two failed to quite add up and instead, Alan Pardew moved north-east leaving Jol, eventually, to join Fulham. While Pardew trusts Fulham will be tired by their long Europa League trip to Ukrainian side Dnipro on Thursday night, his strikers will have to find a way beyond Aaron Hughes, Jol's former Newcastle centre-half. The promising Haris Vuckic and Sammy Ameobi will be hoping to make Pardew's side. Louise Taylor

Do not sell to your rivals, says one of football's laws, and there was a time very recently when Manchester City would not entertain the idea with Tottenham. Harry Redknapp even accused City of bullying tactics, when both clubs chased Craig Bellamy in January 2009. Yet City's decision to allow Emmanuel Adebayor to move to White Hart Lane illustrates how they have stepped up a level. Tottenham will attempt to show that the gap can be bridged in this early season pointer, when attention will be on Luka Modric and Samir Nasri. David Hytner

Having started the season with defeats to Manchester United and Chelsea, Albion host Stoke – who have not lost at The Hawthorns under Tony Pulis – still seeking their first points of the season. Confidence should nonetheless be soaring in the attack, where Shane Long has two goals in two games and could be joined by last season's top scorer, Peter Odemwingie, fully recovered from an ankle injury. Pulis, delighted by Stoke's European progress this week, will be similarly enthused at having Robert Huth, Matthew Etherington and Jonathan Woodgate back and fresh. Georgina Turner

The season is still to take shape but Arsenal must be dismayed to have collected one point so far while also being crushed 8-2 at Old Trafford. Arsène Wenger has signed several players and, although that was essential, the newcomers now have to show that they have improved the squad rather than merely increasing the numbers. Swansea's registration of the former Leeds United defender Fede Bessone has been confirmed and it is likely that all their defenders will be put to the test at the Emirates Stadium. Kevin McCarra

Sir Alex Ferguson has been saying six teams could win the league this season but it's safe to assume Bolton are not among them. They are, however, strengthened by three deadline-beating recruits, including David Ngog, who cost £4m from Liverpool. Also in the Bolton squad are two loan signings, Chelsea's Gaël Kakuta and Dedryck Boyata from Manchester City. United, again without the injured Rafael da Silva and Nemanja Vidic, are expected to give Javier Hernández his first start of the season, in place of Danny Welbeck. Joe Lovejoy

Protest is in the air at Goodison Park, where the Blue Union will stage a march before kick-off over Everton's "stagnation" under Bill Kenwright, and David Moyes will be anxious the atmosphere does not hinder a team low on form and strikers. The departures of Jermaine Beckford and Yakubu Ayegbeni, an injury to Victor Anichebe and Louis Saha's fitness issues means Moyes has only one forward available – Denis Stracqualursi, the Argentinian brought in on loan last week. Aston Villa should have new signings Jermaine Jenas and Alan Hutton in their squad. Andy Hunter

Manchester City's perfect start to the season suggests Wigan's own undefeated streak, which stretches back seven games to the tail end of last season, is under severe threat. The hosts are likely to welcome Micah Richards back following the defender's recovery from a hamstring injury, while Samir Nasri is also in contention to make his home debut for City having recovered from a broken finger. Roberto Martínez, the Wigan manager, could hand debuts to Patrick van Aanholt, Shaun Maloney and Albert Crusat. Amitai Winehouse

There is a buoyancy to both of these teams given their undefeated starts to the season, and with the respective managers having also acquired a host of fresh recruits prior to the close of the transfer window it feels likely this fixture will be characterised by a sense of adventure and renewed excitement. Among the new signings likely to feature is Peter Crouch and he will hope to mark his Stoke debut with a goal against his former club. Liverpool, meanwhile, may unleash Craig Bellamy following his return to Anfield. Sachin Nakrani

An unbeaten but somewhat unimpressive Chelsea face a Sunderland side who have yet to win this season. The hosts shocked Chelsea last season with a 3-0 victory at Stamford Bridge but the visitors' manager, André Villas-Boas, will take comfort from this team's record of having won 12 of the last 13 meetings between these sides. New signings Nicklas Bendtner and Raul Meireles could make their debuts for their respective sides but Sunderland are without another of their strikers, Asamoah Gyan, who is injured. Amitai Winehouse

Seeing their team heavily beaten by the two Manchester clubs in their opening two fixtures was hugely disappointing for Tottenham supporters, but losing at Wolves after a week in which Rafael van der Vaart with a hamstring injury might create real panic. Mick McCarthy's team beat the best at Molineux last season and in taking two wins and a draw from their first three games, look to have taken a step forward. Just one goal conceded in their first three games of 2011-12 suggests Roger Johnson is turning out to be a superb signing for Wolves. Richard Rae

These sides have endured spluttering starts to the season, so something will have to give at Craven Cottage. Intrigue will be provided by the new signings to be blooded by both, with Bryan Ruiz an eye-catching addition for the hosts and Blackburn hoping their strengthening down the spine of their side will produce instant dividends. Steve Kean was in India last week meeting the owners, Venky's, though those did not apparently constitute crisis talks. "They're happy," said the manager. Yet he will be anxious to kickstart his club's campaign at Fulham, where he spent eight years with the academy and as assistant manager. Dominic Fifield

The last time Norwich were in the Premier League it took 14 games before they recorded their first win, so their three matches without victory is nothing to panic about. But back when the fixtures were announced, plenty of Canaries will have earmarked this game as a fine chance to get off the mark. The 20-year-old Declan Rudd will deputise in goal, with John Ruddy out through suspension. West Bromwich, meanwhile, have been better than their record of three defeats suggests. Shane Long is doubtful to make the starting line-up, but Peter Odemwingie should be fit despite missing international duty with Nigeria due to an ankle problem. John Ashdown

Tony Fernandes's first home match as the QPR owner should prove a humdinger. Under the Loftus Road lights, and in front of the live TV cameras, Joey Barton makes his bow for Neil Warnock's side against his former club, Newcastle United. While his acrimonious departure from St James' Park provides a spicy sideshow, both managers will want to get on with accruing points. Alan Pardew has overcome being unable to reinvest most of the £35m yielded from Andy Carroll's sale on a replacement striker to take an impressive seven points from three games, while Warnock's tally is three. Each would be content with a draw. Jamie Jackson

A half-time rollicking from Alex McLeish helped Villa scrape a draw at Everton last week after a first period that the manager described as 'insipid'. The Scot will expect his side to begin much better this week, as they usually do at home. I f they oblige, the front trio of Darren Bent, Charles N'Zogbia and the in-form Gabriel Agbonlahor certainly have the wherewithal to puncture a Newcastle defence that, partially through luck, has conceded just once in four league matches so far. Richard Dunne, in particular, looked jaded last week following his international exertions but, assuming he has recovered, can be expected to be back to his best: it is difficult so see the visitors outscoring Villa. Newcastle's unbeaten streak to end. Paul Doyle

Confident, free-flowing play is unlikely to be on show at Ewood Parkon Saturday given the brittle state of these sides. Arsenal may have reacted to their 8-2 humiliation at Old Trafford with a win over Swansea and a hard-fought draw in Dortmund but, as Arsène Wenger accepts, their recovery is not yet complete. Blackburn, meanwhile, are stuck in last place having failed to win any of their opening four league games. Steve Kean, the manager, is under pressure and may not survive what would be a third successive home defeat. Sachin Nakrani

Owen Coyle has subjected himself to repeated viewings of Bolton's 5-0 defeat to Manchester United and came to an unexpected conclusion: it wasn't as depressing as he had first thought. So while the Wanderers manager has the option of giving a first league start to Tuncay Sanli or David Ngog, mass changes are unlikely. Norwich's Paul Lambert tends to use his squad more and has first-choice keeper John Ruddy available again after suspension. His deputy, Declan Rudd, saved a penalty in Sunday's 1-0 defeat to West Bromwich, but is likely to revert to the bench. Richard Jolly

After last week's protests attacking the club's failure to sign big name footballers, Goodison Park should see a Real Madrid player in David Moyes's starting line-up. Royston Drenthe may be on loan from the Bernabéu, and not part of José Mourinho's plans, but he is better than nothing. Drenthe scored for Everton's reserves on Wednesday night and is likely to start against Wigan. With Antolín Alcaraz and Steve Gohouri out through injury and Emmerson Boyce doubtful with a hamstring strain, Athletic's manager Roberto Martínez has few defensive options after the Carling Cup defeat at Crystal Palace. Tim Rich

Swansea are the only team in the Premier League not to have scored this season, and the last thing they need is to start leaking goals at the back. In that context, it is of major concern that they have lost centre-half Steven Caulker, their loan signing from Tottenham, with cartilage trouble, and Kemy Agustien (hamstring), who has been doing a sterling job in front of the back four. Garry Monk, the club captain, is fit to replace Caulker and Agustien's place is expected to go to Joe Allen. Albion are also without a centre-back, Gabriel Tamas, banned after elbowing James Vaughan when his side won 1-0 at Norwich last week. Craig Dawson, who scored twice on debut for the England Under-21s a fortnight ago, is the likely deputy for Tamas. Chris Brunt will have a test on his troublesome knee and Zoltan Gera (ankle) is definitely out. Joe Lovejoy

Wolves should be afraid, very afraid, if Neil Warnock is to be believed: the QPR manager reckons his new look side, captained by reformed enfant terrible Joey Barton, should have scored 10 against Newcastle last week. On the other hand, the fact the Wolves badge was photographed in the cloud formations above Telford this week has prompted suggestions divine influence may be being brought to bear at Molineux. Either way it is of course far, far too early to suggest this is a match which may prove to have an important effect on this season's relegation battle. Richard Rae

Both sides were held to slightly disappointing 1-1 home draws in Europe this week, Fulham in the familiar territory of the Europa League while Manchester City made their Champions League debut. City look to have benefited from the extra day of recovery time, with far fewer injuries to concern their manager, Roberto Mancini, while the hosts have several problems for Martin Jol to address. Dickson Etuhu, Aaron Hughes and both Riise brothers are all struggling to be fit, while Simon Davies is unlikely to return until November. Rich Flower

Manchester United have won their last three matches with Chelsea in all competitions and that reflects the greater progress they have made in renewing their squad. Continuity of management has helped the Old Trafford project, but Chelsea have spent heavily since the January transfer window. André Villas-Boas must hope for impact even if the line-up is accused of being one-paced. Didier Drogba remains out for the visitors with concussion while Michael Essien is not expected to return from a knee injury until February. Kevin McCarra

The Stoke manager Tony Pulis has a welcome selection dilemma with four strikers all pushing for a place. Jon Walters has started every league game this season but he may miss out on Sunday as he has to compete with record signing Peter Crouch, former Sunderland forward Kenwyne Jones, and summer recruit Cameron Jerome – scorer of an important Europa League goal on Thursday. Sunderland's £8m summer signing Connor Wickham could make his first start since signing for Ipswich alongside another new face, Arsenal loanee Nicklas Bendtner. Rich Flower

Harry Redknapp's distaste for the Europa League had veered into parody by the time he fielded just one of the team to have beaten Wolves last Sunday, but the importance he placed on this fixture was genuine. Spurs's early-season form has been dubious and if they are to end their six-month recession then victory against nominal rivals and a team whom they beat twice last season would be a start. This is a big game for Kenny Dalglish, too – the Liverpool manager seemed disproportionately vexed after the defeat by Stoke. James Callow

Less sympathetic souls might joke that this is a relegation six-pointer. After all, Arsenal are one point and two places above Bolton, who are 19th. But after the hopeless defeat to Blackburn last Saturday, Arsène Wenger will view this as a chance to start the healing process, especially as Owen Coyle's strugglers have not picked up a point since the opening day of the season. Even so, Kevin Davies and company will be just as confident about ruffling an Arsenal defence missing Johan Djourou, Sébastien Squillaci and Thomas Vermaelen. Jacob Steinberg

Chelsea's emotional response to the 4-3 penalty shoot-out win over Fulham in the Carling Cup on Wednesday illustrated their keenness to return to winning ways, following the 3-1 defeat at Manchester United last Sunday. André Villas-Boas's team will rate their chances of continuing this momentum against a Swansea side who finally collected their first league goals and win of the season by defeating West Brom 3-0 last weekend. For Villas-Boas, the now perennial Fernando Torres selection question should be easier: despite a bad miss against United, an earlier clever finish suggested his potency may be returning. Jamie Jackson

Losing to Northampton was bad and going down at Blackburn was worse but what really did for Roy Hodgson was Wolves' 1-0 win at Anfield in late December. Both teams go into this match on the back of encouraging Carling Cup wins in midweek and Wolves' 5-0 thrashing of Millwall will help wash away the taste of last Saturday's enfeebled performance against QPR. Liverpool's Martin Skrtel, who was horribly exposed by Gareth Bale at Tottenham, should move to a more familiar central-defensive role to replace the injured Daniel Agger with Martin Kelly coming in at right back. Tim Rich

David Moyes can only dream of having the riches on offer to Roberto Mancini at Manchester City. While the Italian was busy signing Sergio Agüero and Samir Nasri this summer, Moyes was left scouring the loan market for players, which makes it somewhat surprising that Everton have won the last four games between the sides. They could have done without extra-time against West Bromwich in midweek though – not least because City were able to field a reserve side and still beat Birmingham on the same night. Jacob Steinberg

Who needs Andy Carroll when you have Leon Best? With nine goals in his last 12 league starts for Newcastle the Ireland striker, whose lacklustre form on Tyneside contributed to Chris Hughton's sacking last season, is on a hot scoring streak. Indeed, in the Premier League only Wayne Rooney currently boasts a better goals-per-minute ratio than Best. Alan Pardew must trust he is, once again, wearing his shooting boots and ready to outwit Christopher Samba and company on Saturday; particularly as Blackburn have developed an unerring knack of winning here in recent seasons. Louise Taylor

Manchester United have won their first five games and are playing with so much panache you wouldn't discount them emulating the record of 10 straight victories set by Ron Atkinson's team in 1985. The trip to Stoke, however, represents a difficult challenge. "I love the atmosphere there because it makes you play," Sir Alex Ferguson says. "If you don't pay attention, it just engulfs you. You have to perform to get a result." He can be encouraged that Javier Hernández, scorer of both goals in a 2-1 win here last season, has been passed fit after Ashley Cole's scything tackle last Sunday. Daniel Taylor

Fulham's impressive comeback from two goals down to draw against Manchester City last week, coupled with taking Chelsea to penalties in the Carling Cup, means Martin Jol's side will travel to The Hawthorns with more confidence than a record of being the only side in the Premier League yet to win might suggest. An Albion side much changed from last week's feeble defeat at Swansea played well in losing to Everton on Wednesday, giving Roy Hodgson plenty to think about as he searches for a combination to beat his former side and lift the Baggies off the bottom of the table. Richard Rae

None of Wigan's defensive trio of Antolín Alcaraz, Emmerson Boyce and Steve Gohouri is likely to be fit in time for the visit of Tottenham, and Roberto Martínez will also be without the forward Hugo Rodallega, who was injured at Everton last week. Franco Di Santo is in uncharted territory with three league goals already this season, but Spurs arrive having scored four against Liverpool and Emmanuel Adebayor looks sharp. Harry Redknapp is also without several defenders with William Gallas and Michael Dawson still missing and Benoît Assou-Ekotto looking doubtful. Both sides are targeting a clean sheet; their last two meetings have produced only one goal. Georgina Turner

A sense of growing frustration has rather sprung up on Aston Villa. After an encouraging start to the season, the team was booed by their supporters during last week's 1-1 draw with Newcastle before they then lost meekly to Bolton in the Carling Cup on Tuesday. Alex McLeish, the Villa manager, will be keen, therefore, for a positive outcome on Sunday but in QPR comes up against a side in confident mood following their recent 3-0 win at Molineux and, captained by Joey Barton, in no mood to surrender without a fight. Sachin Nakrani

Last weekend's 4-0 victory over Stoke lifted the gloom over Wearside after Sunderland took just two points from their first four Premier League games, but Norwich too must have enjoyed their week after recording their first win of the season at the expense of Bolton at the Reebok. The hosts' defence continues to have a slightly makeshift look to it as they are still without the injured centre-backs Daniel Ayala, Elliott Ward and Zak Whitbread, but as Sylvester will attest, Black Cats should always approach Canaries with caution. Richard Rae

These remain strange days for Aston Villa. The team are undefeated in the Premier League, but having drawn five of their first six games – the most recent being last week's stalemate at Loftus Road – the home supporters are hardly enthused with the manager, Alex McLeish, and still doubt the Scot's credentials following his summer move from Birmingham. On Saturday he comes up against Roberto Martínez, who turned down the chance to take over at Villa Park for what is proving to be yet another season of struggle at Wigan. Sachin Nakrani

The Carlos Tevez affair obscured another bizarre week at Ewood Park, where the failings of a wretched start were laid at the door of the assistant manager, John Jensen, who was sacked on Thursday. He is due to be replaced by the former Chelsea youth-team coach, Paul Clement. For a side that has not kept a clean sheet in 11 matches, it is the absences in defence that will worry the manager, Steve Kean. Martin Olsson is suspended while Scott Dann, Gaël Givet and Michel Salgado were all injured in the 3-1 defeat at Newcastle. Tim Rich

Kenny Dalglish is back at Goodison as Liverpool manager for the first time since the 4-4 FA Cup replay that precipitated his resignation in 1991, but connections to the past are scarce. Everton had plenty of forwards 20 years ago for a start, including a one-time British record-signing in Tony Cottee, while Liverpool were league champions. Now David Moyes must hope Tim Cahill overcomes injury and a goal-scoring drought against rivals who have dominated this fixture in the Premier League era, winning eight of their last 11 trips across Stanley Park. Andy Hunter

After two consecutive draws and a surprisingly jittery defensive display against Basel in midweek, Sir Alex Ferguson will be expecting a marked performance from his side. Nemanja Vidic and Chris Smalling are still out but it is unlikely Norwich have enough mobility in forward areas to overly worry the home defence. Besides, they will likely spend most of the time protecting their own goal, especially if, as expected, Wayne Rooney and Javier Hernández return to the starting line-up. Anything other than a home win would be a major surprise. Paul Doyle

Both these sides are struggling but at least Roy Hodgson, the West Brom manager, has not had to suspend one of his defenders pending club and police investigations into allegations of Class A drug use and sexual assault. With Sunderland having duly barred Titus Bramble from the club, Michael Turner, fit after serious knee trouble, returns to central defence where he must help contain Peter Odemwingie and Shane Long. Should Sunderland stumble, Steve Bruce's managerial future on Wearside will come under severe scrutiny. Louise Taylor

Three consecutive league defeats means Wolves' impressive start to the season has quickly been forgotten, and Mick McCarthy will find it hard to arrest the slide against in-form Newcastle. Alan Pardew's reinvented Magpies are unbeaten in nine top-flight matches, their best run for nine years, and a defence with the best record in the Premier League is giving the midfielder, Yohan Cabaye, the confidence to demonstrate the passing which played such a major part in Lille winning the French double last season. Richard Rae

Fresh from their midweek trip to Valencia, Chelsea return to the less glamorous surroundings of the Reebok aiming to continue their promising start to the season. Only Manchester United have found a way to beat André Villas-Boas' team this season, with the likes of Juan Mata and Daniel Sturridge adding an exuberance that has been lacking at Stamford Bridge in recent times. This spells danger for Bolton, who sit in bottom place having lost five games in a row. It already looks like being a long season for Owen Coyle's men. Jon Vale

Queens Park Rangers' promotion means west London has another Premier League derby fixture. Fulham have not exactly made a stellar start to life under the stewardship of Martin Jol, failing to win any of their first six league games, but Thursday's 2-0 win at Odense in the Europa League on Thursday suggests they are going in the right direction. The same can be said of QPR, who are unbeaten ever since Tony Fernandes took control of the club, and comfortably beat Wolves 3-0 the last time they played away from home. Jon Vale

Stoke travel to South Wales on a high, seventh in the Premier League after last week's creditable draw with Manchester United and having gone top of their Europa League section with a 2-1 victory over the Turkish club Besiktas on Thursday. Matthew Etherington will have a test on a leg injury. Swansea, in contrast, have won just once in their seven league and cup matches and seem ill-equipped to counter their opponents' power game. The hosts' influential midfielder Leon Britton is a doubt with a back problem. Joe Lovejoy

It is far too early to declare that there has been a shift in power in north London, but a win for Tottenham at White Hart Lane would have an impact. Harry Redknapp's side would then lead Arsenal by five points, with a game in hand. visitors did not impress in the narrow Champions League win over Olympiakos and the quality of the squad is open to debate. Nonetheless, three wins in a row for Arsène Wenger's team must have come as a relief, even if those matches were at the Emirates, with Shrewsbury among the defeated teams. Kevin McCarra

It is five years since Everton last lost a league game at Stamford Bridge, David Moyes's side having gone six games without defeat in all competitions against Chelsea with their last reverse coming to a team managed by Guus Hiddink in the 2009 FA Cup final. "Moyes's work is something fantastic," said André Villas-Boas. "Even with all the difficult financial problems they have, Everton is a club that's well organised and should make the English public proud." Yet the visitors will still arrive in south-west London wary. Chelsea are gathering momentum, the vibrancy of their 5-1 humiliation of Bolton in their last game before the international break still fresh in the memory. They are finding their rhythm. Dominic Fifield

With all eyes in Kuala Lumpur on Wigan v Bolton, the north-west's other big derby sees Liverpool bidding to increase Wayne Rooney's woes with another home league win over Manchester United. Anfield will revel in Rooney's international misfortune but despite renewed focus on his hair-trigger temper, the Evertonian from Croxteth has not combusted in this fixture before. Annoyingly for Sir Alex Ferguson, United often have, and memories of Luis Suárez's magnificent display last season should concern the visitors' suspect defence. This will be Kenny Dalglish's 250th league game in charge of Liverpool and he boasts the finest record of all – 150 wins compared to Bob Paisley's 144. Andy Hunter

Neither side has lost a Premier League game this season, although Aston Villa's unbeaten run has caused rather less fuss than City's. Even his fiercest critics in the Holte End have been forced to concede that Alex McLeish has begun well but the blue half of Manchester has been a graveyard for previous Villa managers, who have lost 10 of their last 11 games, whether at Eastlands or Maine Road. Gabriel Agbonlahor has shaken off a back problem but the encounter has come too soon for Sergio Agüero to lead the Manchester City attack. Tim Rich

According to the manager, Paul Lambert, reports of possible international recognition for the likes of Bradley Johnson, Marc Tierney and Wes Hoolahan indicates those who know about these things are beginning to realise Norwich City are "a force" in the Premier League. The Canaries, in ninth, have the same number of points as fellow top-flight new boys Swansea, but while only one place lower in the league, the Swans have lost all three of their away matches to date. Given they were against Manchester City, Arsenal and Chelsea, perhaps that is not entirely surprising, and the visitors will be boosted by the return of the midfielder Leon Britton, hailed by his manager, Brendan Rodgers, as one of the stars of their season so far. Richard Rae

The QPR manager, Neil Warnock, has warned Blackburn to expect a tough encounter despite his side's 6-0 defeat by Fulham in their last match. "[The players' reaction] has been good," he said. "You are bound to be disappointed with a drubbing but it is one of those things." Hopefully there will not be a repeat of the controversy that erupted around last season's FA Cup meeting between these sides – Warnock compared El-Hadji Diouf to a "sewer rat" after he abused Jamie Mackie while the forward was receiving treatment for a broken leg. Rich Flower

Tony Pulis, the Stoke manager will wait on the fitness of Matthew Etherington after the winger had a sugar injection in an ailing back. Stoke are far from sweet with four league goals to their name this season – Fulham's Andy Johnson has six in his last three games in all competitions – but they remain unbeaten at home. With Jermaine Pennant and Kenwyne Jones likely to be out, Etherington's presence could be key against a Fulham side that crushed QPR 6-0 in their last Premier League outing and have kept four consecutive clean sheets. James Callow

These two clubs are separated by small margins. There are only two points between them in the Premier League's relegation zone, and pessimism prevails along the seven-mile Lancashire corridor that connects them. Given their comparative stretches of form – Wigan have experienced four straight defeats while a seventh consecutive loss for bottom-placed Bolton would be their worst sequence in the top flight since 1903 – this is more likely to be a thud-and-blunder derby settled by a single goal than the expansive encounter venerated by managers Roberto Martínez and Owen Coyle. Richard Gibson

It feels as if the international break has diluted the sense of unease at both of these clubs but the spotlight will be back on the loser. Or, in the case of a draw, Arsenal. Arsène Wenger was in relaxed mood and he joked at the expense of the reporters. "The speciality is to get bad news in the newspapers so it's not worth spoiling your breakfast," said the avid reader. Here is some more negativity for him – no team with less than eight points after seven games has finished in the Premier League's top four, although three sides have made fifth. David Hytner

Anyone who counts on St James' Park for volatility must be a little disappointed. An unbeaten Newcastle United are fourth and, for the moment, the club has in Alan Pardew a manager surely enjoying a small sense of security. All the same, Tottenham would have 15 points too, if they won their game in hand. An away fixture of this sort will help to indicate the prospects of Harry Redknapp's side finishing in the top four this season. It remains to be seen if they can score enough goals on their travels – Emmanuel Adebayor's fitness may be crucial. Kevin McCarra

Black Country derbies are traditionally fiercely contested matches but this one feels like it has additional significance. Wolves are desperate to end a run of four successive defeats while Albion have won only once in seven league matches and could well be in the bottom three come kick-off. With Steven Fletcher ruled out after picking a calf injury, Mick McCarthy seems likely to revert to a 4-5-1 formation. Albion, on the other hand, are boosted by the availability of Peter Odemwingie, who badly needs a goal to get his season going. Stuart James

West Bromwich Albion have failed to win at Villa Park since 1982, although Roy Hodgson's side could be forgiven for believing this fixture represents a decent chance to bring that dismal run to an end, especially if their opponents defend like they did against Manchester City last Saturday. The return of James Collins to the centre of the Villa defence should make a difference. Hodgson's main selection dilemma is whether to start Peter Odemwingie, who came off the bench to score against Wolves last week. Zoltan Gera is expected to be among the substitutes. Stuart James

Too early for this to be a relegation six-pointer? Both teams have accrued just six points to leave Bolton a place below Sunderland in third-bottom due to inferior goal difference – so Owen Coyle and Steve Bruce would admit privately that this a match each dare not lose. Sunderland have not won since Stoke were beaten 4-0 over a month ago so Bruce's position must be under pressure. The word is that Coyle is currently more secure with last week's timely 3-1 win at Wigan, a result that ended his side's six-match losing streak. Jamie Jackson

The Norwich manager Paul Lambert has promised that his side will "give it a go" at Anfield on Saturday. The Canaries adopted a similar approach at Old Trafford and Stamford Bridge earlier this season and although both games ended in defeat for the visitors, the performances were encouraging. Make no mistake, though, this will be tough for the visitors, who are still without their preferred centre-back pairing of Elliott Ward and Zak Whitbread. They will also be facing a virtually full-strength Liverpool with the suspended Lucas Leiva expected to be the only absentee. Rich Flower

A manager's injury list frequently serves as a decent litmus test of both his popularity and general squad morale. After an unbeaten beginning to the season, it is perhaps not entirely coincidental that Alan Pardew has virtually a full complement of fit players to choose from. Even better for the Newcastle manager, there is strong competition for places in several key positions. Roberto Martínez lacks similar options but the Wigan manager will be delighted to welcome his key striker, Hugo Rodallega, back from injury as the vistiors aim to arrest a run of five straight league defeats. Louise Taylor

When Wolves briefly led the Premier League in August, Mick McCarthy gave a knowing smile and said it would never last. But even this most pragmatic of Yorkshiremen would not have envisaged his team's slump since. Five successive defeats, three of them at home, have drained confidence at Molineux, and the recent injury to top scorer Steven Fletcher has not brightened the mood. Swansea could be the perfect opposition – they have lost all four away league games so far this season, conceding 12 goals in the process. Paul Chronnell

Depending on your level of empathy, the fact Arsenal have won five out of their last six matches is either a corner turned, or a false position given the calibre of some of the opposition. Outside the top four, there would appear to be no team better than Stoke to test how much progress Arsenal have made in terms of defensive solidity. The partnership between Per Mertersacker and Laurent Koscielny, with Alex Song clearing up in front, worked well in the Champions League, but dealing with Rory Delap's throws and the dimensions of Peter Crouch and Kenwyne Jones is a whole new ball game. Stoke, however, have endured hangovers after their European excursions this season, losing heavily against Swansea and Sunderland. Besides, their status as a bogey team for Arsenal heavily relates to the Britannia Stadium – Arsène Wenger's side have won their last nine home games against the Potters. Amy Lawrence

Rover fans plan another "Kean Out" protest, and with his team bottom of the table, it is debatable whether Steve Kean deserves support. Yakubu Ayegbeni insists the manager has it from the team, to which Kean could reply that it was a pity they were not showing it on the field. For Sunday, Míchel Salgado joins David Dunn, Vince Grella and Ryan Nelsen on the injured list. Despite another crop of casualties, to which they seem particularly prone, the odds favour Tottenham, who are unbeaten in their last nine in all competitions. Ledley King is yet again among the absentees, who also include William Gallas, Michael Dawson and Vedrun Corluka. Joe Lovejoy

The season might already feel like a slog for both clubs. Fulham are fresh (or otherwise) from their 20th match, in the Europa League at Wisla Krakow on Thursday, and are groping for domestic results, while Everton are labouring under a weight of pessimism induced by stark realities. David Moyes's ability to punch his way out of a financial straitjacket is being tested yet again. His team need a tonic, after three successive league defeats; they have not suffered four on the spin since December 2005. Fulham, though, are tough to beat at home. David Hytner

The weight of City's wealth has not left too much of a dent in United's standing so far. Sir Alex Ferguson's side did lose last season's FA Cup semi-final, but they have won five of the past six league encounters. City's hope must be that they are still progressing, despite the fact that regeneration is taking place at United as well. If there is a key change to be seen at City it must lie in the enhanced attacking of a side that has narrowly outscored United. At Old Trafford, though, the capacity of Roberto Mancini's team to contain will be critical. Kevin McCarra

QPR have not won this derby since 1995, albeit only seven meetings ago, so this would be a timely occasion to end their 15-year wait for a home win in the top flight. They have shown only flashes of form to date this term at Loftus Road as a hastily assembled squad become familiar with each other. Chelsea, in contrast, appear to be adjusting to life under André Villas-Boas and have found their rhythm. The trio of John Terry, Juan Mata and Didier Drogba will surely return to the starting line-up as the visitors aim to take advantage of the only two sides above them in the table meeting at Old Trafford. Dominic Fifield

Arsène Wenger will lock horns with a ninth different Chelsea manager in his 15 years at Arsenal and will hope André Villas-Boas is not the second coming of José Mourinho as Arsenal did not win this fixture during the reign of the Blues' first Portuguese leader. Wenger will be glad his injury-ravaged defence will not have to face the suspended Didier Drogba, scorer of 13 goals in 14 games against Arsenal. His replacement, Fernando Torres, can only dream of such statistics in a blue shirt, but may well fancy his chances on Saturday. Paul Chronnell

A win at Aldershot in the Carling Cup cannot count as catharsis for Manchester United. Following the 6-1 loss at Old Trafford in the derby match, it is this game that will tell us most about the manner in which Sir Alex Ferguson's side has regrouped. The fixture is seldom simple. United have not won at Goodison since September 2007 and Everton scored twice at the very end of last season's game for a 3-3 draw. The hosts' prospects this weekend will depend on improving their current home form. They have had one league win there in four attempts. Kevin McCarra

Wolves may have halted their worst run since 1991 with last week's draw against Swansea but Mick McCarthy will be realistic enough to realise that his side will struggle to return to winning ways on Saturday. Wolves beat Manchester City in the reverse fixture last season but as City's 5-2 Carling Cup win at Molineux on Wednesday showed, Roberto Mancini's men are a much-changed side. The Italian is likely to name the same side that beat Manchester United last week while Steven Fletcher remains out injured for the visitors. Ian McCourt

Blackburn's home games have been marred by the protests against Steve Kean, so an away trip will provide some welcome relief for the beleaguered manager. History may be on his side – Blackburn have won four and lost none of their last eight matches in all competitions against Norwich, and they recorded a victory over Newcastle in the Carling Cup on Wednesday. But the hosts have lost just one of their last 16 league games at Carrow Road and will be looking to build on last week's encouraging draw with Liverpool. Ian McCourt

If the news that Titus Bramble, the Sunderland defender currently serving an indefinite club suspension, had been charged with two counts of sexual assault was not bad enough for the home supporters, Darren Bent is back on Wearside. Sunderland fans had their hearts broken when the striker defected to Villa for £24m last January and Steve Bruce, seeking what would be only a third home victory since New Year's Day, could certainly do without Bent scoring against his side. Meanwhile, Jermaine Jenas hopes to finally make his debut for Villa having joined on loan from Tottenham in August. Louise Taylor

Swansea are strong at home and poor away, Bolton abysmal at home and strong away – with both sides on their preferred territory, something has got to give. Owen Coyle's side have lost more games than any other Premier League team this season and come into this fixture off a spirited, if ultimately unsuccessful, effort against Arsenal in the Carling Cup in midweek. "If we give a performance of the level of that from the other night, then more often than not it will result in positive points," said the Bolton manager. "Swansea have very good home form and we have very good away form, so it makes for a very good game." John Ashdown

After two consecutive 1-1 home draws, Liverpool will be keen to get back to winning ways on Saturday and should be buoyed by their midweek victory over Stoke in the Carling Cup. But a stern test awaits them. West Bromwich Albion have won their last two league games and despite the absence of top-scorer Shane Long with a long-term knee injury, the hosts will feel they can win again. They should fear Luis Suárez, however, who scored both of the visitors' goals at the Britannia Stadiumon Wednesday, the first of which was a masterly finish. Sachin Nakrani

Two managers meet at DW Stadium tomorrow grateful for the faith showed in them by their paymasters. Wigan Athletic almost never win but Roberto Martínez's seat remains among the safest in the Premier League, while Martin Jol received a high-profile pat on the back this week when the Fulham owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, described the Dutchman as the manager he always wanted in a tit-for-tat with Mark Hughes. The feeling of bonhomie may dissipate, though; the team which loses this match will end the day in the bottom three. James Callow

A second London derby in a week for Queens Park Rangers sees them travel to White Hart Lane, where all those involved with the club will attempt for a few hours at least to forget about the furore caused by John Terry's alleged racist comments towards the defender Anton Ferdinand. The controversy has rather overshadowed the achievement of Neil Warnock's side in beating Chelsea last Sunday for the first time in 16 years, but in Tottenham they face a team that has dropped only two points in their last six league games. Saad Noor

Stoke did the double over Newcastle last season, beating them 4-0 at home and 2-1 away, but Newcastle are a more formidable and creative force now. They have conceded the fewest goals in the league and, along with Manchester City, are the only team yet to lose. But Stoke remain difficult to beat on their own turf, having lost just one of their last 13 league fixtures at the Britannia Stadium. Steven Taylor is likely to play for Newcastle, possibly with a mask due to a nose injury, while Jonathan Woodgate is in line to face his former club. Ian McCourt

This fixture caused a shock last term, as West Brom won at Arsenal, deservedly, with a performance full of punch and panache. For something similar to happen this time, Roy Hodgson needs more belief from his team than they showed in an inhibited display last weekend against Liverpool. "Too much respect" was the phrase that the manager used. Maximum respect is due to Robin van Persie, who will surely be back in the starting line-up, along with fit-again Thomas Vermaelen. Arsenal are hoping to shake off Champions League fatigue and rediscover that Stamford Bridge verve. Amy Lawrence

Alex McLeish expects to offer an overdue debut to the on-loan midfielder Jermaine Jenas who has recovered from an achilles injury, while Barry Bannan is also welcomed back into the squad. Only a win would leapfrog Villa above Norwich in the table, who sit in eighth place. Their dream start to the season is thanks in no small part to the striker Grant Holt, who has scored equalisers for Norwich in their last two fixtures. However, if he is to repeat those heroics tomorrow, he will likely to be asked to do so again from the bench. Benji Inwood

Ewood Park plays host to two sides experiencing very different problems. Blackburn's home games this season have been notable for poor performances on the pitch and vocal protests off it, even if there have been some signs of improvement in their past two outings. Chelsea have been uncharacteristically flimsy as the investigation into their captain John Terry plays out in the media. Terry is nonetheless expected to start against Rovers after watching the 1-1 draw with Genk from the substitutes' bench. Benji Inwood

If Swansea were as good away as they are at home, Liverpool may have something to fear. But they are not. The sixth-placed hosts will not want to replicate the profligate display that led to Grant Holt's equaliser for Norwich in their last home game and Luis Suárez – always the chief threat – will want to add to his tally having not scored in his last three league games. Liverpool were better at the back without Jamie Carragher at West Brom and Swansea's in-form Danny Graham may struggle if isolated as a lone striker. Gregg Roughley

After scoring 21 goals in their first five Premier League fixtures Manchester United have managed only six in the last five and lost the fluency that made them so irresistible in the opening weeks of the season. Even so, it would constitute a major surprise if Sunderland, with only one victory against United in 20 attempts, were to do anything to deny Sir Alex Ferguson a satisfying 25th anniversary. Steve Bruce, returning to his former club, has assembled a squad with a heavy United influence but one of the old boys, John O'Shea, misses out because of injury. Daniel Taylor

Things are going so well on Tyneside that Alan Pardew was required to body-swerve questions about his eligibility for the England job this week. Newcastle remain undefeated in the league this season but, well aware Everton can be awkward guests, Pardew was at pains not to underestimate the tactical duel ahead. "David Moyes is one of the best managers in the world and he's got some good players," he said. "If we can even get a point against Everton and stay unbeaten that would be fantastic." Louise Taylor

There can't be all that much disquiet at a newly-promoted club that beat Chelsea in its last home match. Without checking the optimism, the manager, Neil Warnock, will still know how difficult this season could yet be for QPR. That 3-1 defeat at White Hart Lane was an insight into the standard the leading sides can set. Manchester City are even more formidable and have scored 27 goals in seven games since losing to Bayern Munich. City's capacity to change the side and still win at Villarreal was an unnecessary reminder of the resources. Kevin McCarra

Owen Coyle has praised the Bolton Wanderers fans, who have continued to support him despite the fact that their team are yet to pick up a single point at home this season. Stoke City arrive at the Reebok on the back of an impressive victory away to Maccabi Tel Aviv, but Tony Pulis is acutely aware of the challenge facing his side and must wait on several players to prove their fitness. "We have a point to prove on Sunday and that is can we go somewhere and get a result after a European game?" the Stoke manager said. Benji Inwood

Martin Jol left Tottenham Hotspur under a cloud, ushered out a side door and replaced by Juande Ramos after his efforts were judged mediocre. Yet the Dutchman can still count upon residual goodwill from his former club, who will wait to have Harry Redknapp back at the helm following heart surgery. Fulham may have had 72 hours' rest following their impressive 4-1 win over Wisla Krakow but Spurs fielded an almost entirely second-string line-up in Kazan on Thursday. Will rhythm prove more valuable than freshness? James Callow

It is more than 32 years since Wolves last won at Goodison Park. In 1979-80 John Barnwell's side went on to finish sixth in the top flight, a high water mark they have failed to match since, and those currently wearing the old gold will not be eclipsing that achievement this season (or anytime soon, in truth) but they did show signs of improvement in the win against Wigan. Everton will hope their England performers – Jack Rodwell and Phil Jagielka in particular – bring their international form back to the Premier League. John Ashdown

Newcastle's visit to the Etihad Stadium brings an unexpected collision of high-flying mutual excellence. The Premier League's two remaining unbeaten records are on the line as the division's meanest defence – Alan Pardew's keenly-drilled all-sorts – meets the most prolific attack. There have been suggestions Newcastle's run is rooted in an unusually clement run of fixtures and that Saturday's game will give a clearer indication of their quality. Pardew's hopes of proving otherwise are aided by the absence of Samir Nasri and the wearying effects on City's powerful squad of a week of globetrotting international service. Barney Ronay

Norwich have yet to keep a clean sheet in the league this season, and are unlikely to relish the visit of an Arsenal side that score freely away from home. The Canaries have not been helped by the continued absence of the central defender, Elliott Ward – whom manager Paul Lambert revealed on Friday could be require an operation on an ongoing knee injury – a situation that has seen Russell Martin playing out of position for most of the season. Arsenal's long-running unbeaten record at Carrow Road does not bode well either. Rich Flower

For Tony Pulis and his floundering Stoke team the international break may just have come at an opportune moment. After an abject performance in the 5-0 thrashing by struggling Bolton, a fortnight's break has given Pulis the chance to reorganise and also time for players such as Matthew Etherington, Ryan Shawcross and Marc Wilson to recover from injury. All are expected to be involved at some point on Saturday, but whether the Potters are able to take advantage of the respite against a resilient QPR side remains to be seen. Rich Flower

The aim of these sides is to shake the other one off. Both are locked on 10 points, having won two, drawn four and lost five of their first 11 matches of the season and neither can escape the prospect of a winter spent in the relegation zone should they lose again on Saturday. Sunderland can take heart from how they performed in their last game – the 1-0 loss at Manchester United – but will fret given the absence of top scorer Sebastian Larsson. Fulham, meanwhile, are aiming to win a second successive away league fixture. Sachin Nakrani

This promises to be a fascinating fixture. Swansea are unbeaten at home in the Premier League and have conceded only one goal in 450 minutes of football at the Liberty Stadium but the visit of Manchester United represents the first major test on their own patch. United will be boosted by the return of Ashley Young but Danny Welbeck joins Michael Owen, Tom Cleverley and Chris Smalling on the sidelines. Brendan Rodgers must decide whether to restore the fit-again Scott Sinclair to a team that has enjoyed more possession than United this season. Stuart James

The international break came at exactly the wrong time for Bolton Wanderers. A thumping 5-0 win against Stoke had given the club impetus for the first time in an otherwise miserable season, only for Owen Coyle's team to be either scattered to their national sides or forced to spend two weeks on the training pitch. Albion lost their assistant manager in the break – Michael Appleton taking the top job at Portsmouth – but will be hungry to get back to winning ways after successive defeats at the hands of Liverpool and Arsenal. John Ashdown

On the first anniversary of Venky's buying Rovers, Steve Kean faces another demonstration by seriously cheesed-off fans who will end their "week of mourning" by pitching up outside the DW Stadium to voice their disquiet. Only Wigan are below Rovers at the bottom with Roberto Martínez requiring victory as desperately as Kean. Each club's dismal record shows a sole win and only 11 goals scored between them from a combined 22 outings. Wigan's victory was on 27 August, Rovers' on 17 September. So far no Premier League manager has been sacked: defeat today could change that. Jamie Jackson

It is hardly a crisis for a club to be fourth in the table when there are still another 27 fixtures to come, but the demands are always great at Chelsea. Even if the manager, André Villas-Boas, can only be concerned by the goals conceded so regularly, there is comfort in both the firepower, and some very good days that have ensued. Liverpool, with little more than a goal a game in the Premier League, look outmatched in attack, but they happen to have won their last two away matches in this competition, at West Bromwich and Everton. Kevin McCarra

By the sound of it, Harry Redknapp is eager to return to the technical area, following heart surgery. The craving to be involved in the game is sharp for any manager, but there is a particular attraction for one whose side is doing well. Tottenham have not been beaten in the league since the crushing 5-1 loss to Manchester City at White Hart Lane in August. Following that result, the team appear to have found flamboyance, scoring two goals or more in each of the eight league fixtures that have followed. Villa have not won away this season. Kevin McCarra

What crisis? Arsenal's revival after the dark weeks of the early season has temporarily mocked the naysayers and reinforced the veracity of several adages, chief among them the hilarity of this old game. There is also the one that says "Arsène knows". With the unforgiving spotlight transferred to Chelsea, the Arsenal support will hope to revel in a sixth straight league win. Fulham's ex-Tottenham manager, Martin Jol, once squared up to Wenger on the touchline. "He obviously hadn't seen the size of my fists," Jol said. The scale of Fulham's challenge is clear. David Hytner

Bolton are enduring the most curious of seasons, winning 4-0 away on the opening day and then losing their next six. Victory at Wigan and the 5-0 hammering of Stoke seemed to suggest a corner had been turned, but last week's reverse at The Hawthorns was depressingly familiar for Owen Coyle's side. David Moyes could empathise given Everton's struggles, which have not been helped by the continued absence of Jack Rodwell and Phil Neville. Bolton are the only top-flight side not to have drawn so far. This could be it. Paul Chronnell

André Villas-Boas is as optimistic as he can be ahead of this one but he knows the poorest start of any Chelsea manager under Roman Abramovich cannot afford to continue with defeat to Wolves. The 34-year-old is flailing a little as he struggles to defend his "high line" defence, a system that Mick McCarthy hopes to exploit by informing his players to lift aerial balls over the top to test John Terry's creaking legs. Wolves, in 17th and two points clear of danger, could do with a win: but they won't get one here, will they…? Jamie Jackson

Manchester United followed their 6-1 pasting at the hands of their city neighbours with five successive clean sheets, but the 2-2 draw with Benfica in midweek echoed former insecurities. United have regressed (or, depending on your point of view, progressed) into grind mode in the Premier League – a trio of 1-0s have seen them keep pace with the leaders but win few plaudits. Newcastle will fancy their chances of escaping Old Trafford with a point, despite the probable absence of their combative midfielder, Cheick Tioté. John Ashdown

Neil Warnock was only able to name five substitutes for last weekend's 3-2 win at Stoke, and a lengthy injury list means the QPR manager may have to face a similar dilemma on Saturday. The situation is exacerbated by the absence of Joey Barton, who is suspended after picking up five yellow cards, although Heidar Helguson, scorer of five goals in his last five games, has been passed fit. Norwich have fewer fitness concerns, and Zak Whitbread could make the squad for the first time since August after recovering from a hamstring problem. Rich Flower

While attention has been focused on Steve Kean's struggles at Blackburn, Stoke have got off to their worst start in a Premier League season: they have lost their last four league games and are now just three points above the relegation places. Jonathan Woodgate is fit for the home side but Peter Crouch is a doubt with a groin injury and will have a late fitness test. The same injury is likely to rule out Blackburn's Chris Samba, whose side picked up a sliver of momentum with their thrilling comeback to draw 3-3 with Wigan last weekend. Tom Lutz

Does a watershed moment beckon for Steve Bruce? Considering his stuttering Sunderland side have won only twice at home since New Year's Day and Wigan are bottom it certainly looks that way. "Sunderland will feel that, with the money they have spent, they should beat a team like ours," said Roberto Martínez, cranking up the pressure on the manager he succeeded at Wigan. "That is an entirely understandable level of expectation." Victims of refereeing error against Blackburn last week, Martínez's players are likely to be in wounded animal mode. "We are hurting," he said. "We feel we are owed some points." Louise Taylor

Roy Hodgson hailed a near-perfect performance by his side after last week's win over Bolton and expressed his bemusement at their inability to play like that every week. They will probably have to if they are to stand any chance of disturbing Tottenham, who have slipped into a formidable groove. Albion can trouble the Spurs defence, but with Emmanuel Adebayor and Rafael van der Vaart in impressive form, they are unlikely to be able to subdue the visitors' attacking prowess. An away win in a high-scoring game could be on the cards. Paul Doyle

It should be harder for Liverpool and virtually every other club in England to keep pace with Manchester City. Nonetheless, Roberto Mancini's side can be in no doubt about the hunger they inspire in the opposition. City, indeed, are in trouble in the Champions League now because Napoli rose to the occasion on Tuesday. This match will show whether Manicini's squad can regroup against a Liverpool side who are unbeaten in their last nine matches in all competitions following the 2-1 defeat of Chelsea last weekend. Kevin McCarra

Aston Villa are one of only two teams outside the relegation zone not to have won away, so a trip to Swansea could be a daunting prospect for a side who have tended towards flakiness at times this season, having thrown away nine points from winning positions. Only two visiting clubs have scored at the Liberty Stadium in 2011-12, and only one of those – Manchester United – have left with all three points, so Villa will be hoping that their captain and midfield lynchpin, Stilian Petrov, overcomes a hamstring strain and is able to start. Rich Flower

Alex McLeish could have been forgiven if he had watched Manchester United's midweek Carling Cup defeat at the hands of Crystal Palace with his head in his hands. His Villa side could well face the backlash on Saturday evening. Sir Alex Ferguson insisted he was happy with his side's form after the quarter-final loss but must be concerned with United's faltering firepower – his side have not scored more than one goal in a league game since the 2-0 win over Norwich on 1 October. Still, Villa currently look ill-equipped to take advantage. John Ashdown

Dare Steve Kean lose this match against Swansea City, who arrive at Ewood Park seven points and seven places better off than his bottom-placed Blackburn Rovers? Only three wins separate Rovers from Aston Villa in eighth, so there is still time for Kean to pull the club from the mire. But the beleaguered Scot has to start doing so soon and in precisely this kind of fixture. If Brendan Rodgers' troops hand Rovers a ninth league defeat then Venky's, the owners, may have to start considering a managerial change. Jamie Jackson

Manchester City's draw at Liverpool last week was the first time they have not managed two or more goals in any of their league fixtures. They are only the fourth club in the Premier League era to be unbeaten after 13 games and, going back to last season, have now scored in 19 successive matches. Yet Norwich have already given Manchester United a scare and drawn at Liverpool, and they will be encouraged that their hosts have not kept a clean sheet in their last six league games, their longest run under Roberto Mancini. Daniel Taylor

A game that André Villas-Boas could certainly do without losing is the first Newcastle will play since the death of former midfielder Gary Speed – a member of Sir Bobby Robson's famous "Blue Chip Brigade". "Everyone's a bit low," said Alan Pardew, the Newcastle manager, who will again be without Cheik Tioté. Arguably Pardew's best player – not to mention a midfielder much coveted by Chelsea – Tioté has been sidelined by knee trouble since late October but Newcastle remain hopeful that surgery can be avoided. Louise Taylor

Two teams struggling for consistency meet at Loftus Road. Queens Park Rangers, in particular, have perplexed their followers with the manner in which they have switched from victory to defeat from one week to the next. Most recently, a 3-2 win at Stoke was followed by a 2-1 loss at Norwich and, as such, it is difficult to say with certainty how they will fare against a West Bromwich Albion side that has just lost Zoltan Gera to injury for the rest of the season. Joey Barton, meanwhile, returns from suspension for the hosts. Sachin Nakrani

Bolton's 4-0 win at Loftus Road on the opening day might feel some way away as the club returns to London in the relegation zone and preparing to face one of the country's in-form teams. Gary Cahill could have been lining up for Tottenham had Daniel Levy been able to close a deal on transfer deadline day, instead the defender will be charged with shackling Emmanuel Adebayor, although the threat comes from all angles at White Hart Lane. Harry Redknapp said Bolton had suffered from injuries and bad luck, and are always tough, but this one looks like a home banker. David Hytner

Arsenal's recent resurgence has hit a minor blip with last weekend's draw against Fulham followed by the Carling Cup exit to Manchester City. Arsène Wenger will recall his first XI on Saturday but will be aware that on his last two visits to the north-west his side conceded eight at Old Trafford and then four at Blackburn. Wigan's victory at Sunderland has lifted them off the bottom of the table as well as accounting for Steve Bruce, and they may fancy their chances of taking something from this fixture for the third successive season. Paul Chronnell

Tony Pulis has urged Stoke supporters to "look around and smell the roses" after a club that had never won a European tie before this season became the first in England to reach the last 32 of the Europa League. It is the after-effects, however, that are causing disquiet. Stoke have lost their last four games away in the league, all following European duty, and will need to recapture their steel and cutting edge (they have the division's lowest goals tally on their travels this season) against an Everton side seeking a third straight win. Andy Hunter

Martin O'Neill will not be officially in charge of Sunderland on Sunday, but he will still loom over the game. His new squad has much to prove after failing to win any of their last four matches. This fixture, all the same, involves much more than Sunderland's prospects of recovering status. Wolves, 17th in the table, are immediately behind the visitors on goal difference. With roughly a third of the programme completed, sides can be clearer about their aims. For Mick McCarthy, survival is the ambition. Sunderland will anticipate more than that, yet this match could still illustrate the difficulties O'Neill must address. Kevin McCarra

Mixed emotions will accompany Liverpool on their annual trip to the Thames. The squad will reflect fondly on how they beat the hosts 5-2 in this fixture last season with a breathless and, at times, awesome, attacking display, but there will also be sadness at the recent loss of Lucas Leiva to a season-ending knee injury. The Brazil midfielder has become an integral part of Kenny Dalglish's side and without him they may struggle significantly. Fulham, buoyed by last week's draw at Arsenal, will aim to test the visitors' resolve. Sachin Nakrani

Arsenal stand to start with four central defenders across the back line and an out-of-favour goalkeeper on the bench – Manuel Almunia has been promoted following injuries – but Everton have the patent on battling to make ends meet. David Moyes has had little money to spend and he will be reminded of what he once had when he sees Mikel Arteta in Arsenal red.
