Frustration and inconsistency have clung to Everton but Arteta's new team are back on the up. The Spanish midfielder's contribution has been of the unsung variety. David Hytner

This is not the first time these sides have met this season, with Bolton knocking Alex McLeish's side out of the Carling Cup in late September thanks to goals from Chris Eagles and Gaël Kakuta. But any hope the hosts have of coming away from this match with a win should be tempered by the fact that Owen Coyle's side have lost eight of their last nine matches at home. Villa, meanwhile, have not won any of their seven away league games but will sense that they can depart from Lancashire with all three points. Ian McCourt

All eyes, and no doubt Liverpool's in-house television cameras, will be on Luis Suárez to see what the Premier League's latest pantomime villain gets up to at the end of a week that brought an improper conduct charge for giving the finger to Fulham fans plus another call for greater protection from Kenny Dalglish. But there are other concerns for the Liverpool manager. The league's other promoted sides, Norwich and Swansea, are among those to have held Liverpool to a draw at home and, with midfield options dwindling by the week, QPR will hope to capitalise. Andy Hunter

It feels like a long time since Manchester United opened the season playing with so much freedom and fun, scoring 18 goals in their first four games. They have not managed more than one in each of their last seven league fixtures and Sir Alex Ferguson now has to plan their title defence without their captain, Nemanja Vidic. In the circumstances Wolves might be seen as obliging opponents. They have not won at Old Trafford since 1980 and were beaten 3-0 by a Chelsea side in the grips of their own mini-crisis two weeks ago. Yet Mick McCarthy's players should feel they have a better chance than usual to spring a surprise. Daniel Taylor

Is it too early to suggest Newcastle United's early-season run is over? The problems/challenges are certainly mounting for Alan Pardew after taking just one point from their last three games, and with Steven Taylor probably missing the rest of the season with an achilles injury and his central defensive partner, Fabricio Coloccini, doubtful to face Norwich because of a thigh injury. Paul Lambert's team are in healthy shape, though their last outing was a 5-1 shellacking by Manchester City and, as Norwich are only six points off the relegation zone, the Scot will want a win on Saturday. Jamie Jackson

The last time these sides met in the league was in February 1997; Fulham won 2-1 to go top of what we now know as League Two. They finished the season second behind another current Premier League club, Wigan, with Swansea losing the play-off final. The Swans, whose away results have been the worst in the division and who suffered the ignominy of losing 4-2 at Blackburn last weekend, have a home record bettered only by the current top six and, after one win in seven, will be looking for a positive result on home turf. Simon Burnton

This is a game that seems destined for the basement slot on Match of the Day, and with good reason too. Between them, West Bromwich Albion and Wigan have scored just 25 league goals this season – less than half of Manchester City's total – and are the two least potent teams in the division. An overspill of entertainment is unlikely at The Hawthorns, then, although Wigan may take to the contest with some thrust and determination given their next three fixtures are against Chelsea, Liverpool and Manchester United. Sachin Nakrani

Tottenham Hotspur have turned into a side of great reliability. With five wins and a draw from seven away games in the Premier League, they have been outdone only by the two Manchester clubs, who each have just a point more from their travels. As absentees from the Champions League this season, they have also spared themselves the dismay experienced this week by the sides above them. Stoke, however, have not just beaten an under-strength Tottenham on penalties in the Carling Cup, but held Chelsea and Manchester United at home as well as defeating Liverpool. Kevin McCarra

Martin O'Neill was at Eppleton Colliery Welfare's windswept ground on Thursday watching Sunderland reserves thrash their Manchester United counterparts 6-3 with Ryan Noble scoring four times. O'Neill will surely not dare to dream of marking his debut as Sunderland manager by dissecting Blackburn in similarly ruthless fashion but remains optimistic of choreographing a much needed home win. While Noble, who has recovered from serious back and knee injuries to score 11 goals in seven reserve games, hopes to feature, Blackburn's renascent striker Yakubu plans to spoil the Wearside party. Louise Taylor

This is a Premier League match, but the shadow of the Champions League falls over it. Chelsea have progressed in the latter competition and it now remains to be seen whether André Villas-Boas's side can go on to fulfil the expectations awakened by the appointment of a young manager with a fine track record. Manchester City, eliminated from the Champions League despite beating Bayern Munich in midweek, have to show that the incentive of sustaining their lead on the domestic front will prevent any dip in morale or form. Kevin McCarra

The next two games could be crucial to Steve Kean and Blackburn's chances of survival. Beat West Bromwich Albion and Bolton at home and Kean can relax with his Christmas dinner, safe in the knowledge that his side are moving in the right direction. Lose, however, and he will have a tough time holding on to his job. Roy Hodgson is under no such pressure at The Hawthorns but his side have lost their way of late and only three points separate them from the relegation zone. The high stakes involved will make this a cagey affair. Ian McCourt

Everton will have targeted three points from this game, but Norwich's draw at Anfield and last week's win against Newcastle suggest they will present a tough challenge. The hosts, who need Louis Saha – or anyone – to discover a scoring knack, may find Paul Lambert's bold attacking style to their liking. If only Landon Donovan, due to arrive in January for a second Goodison loan spell, was available sooner to a side also lacking accurate delivery from the flanks and creativity. Ross Barkley's new contract is a bonus but it is time for the last Barkley, Jack Rodwell, to fire. Neil Morton

Bolton are bottom with nine points and last won on 6 November, when Stoke were routed 5-0, to leave Owen Coyle as the latest manager desperate for a win as he arrives at Craven Cottage. Fulham were dumped out of the Europa League on Wednesday by Odense with the game's final touch, but Martin Jol's men are 14th and six points better off than the visitors. The Dutchman selected Bobby Zamora in midweek despite their ongoing disagreement, so whether he gets the nod for this one is an intriguing side-issue. Jamie Jackson

Louise Speed will be on Tyneside to see Newcastle United remember her late husband and their former midfielder, Gary, courtesy of a poignant pre-match tribute. Later, Newcastle's Tim Krul and Swansea's Michel Vorm will endeavour to prove why they should become Holland's first-choice goalkeeper ahead of Euro 2012. Much may depend on whether the much-coveted Cheik Tioté – or "our warrior" as Alan Pardew calls him – passes a late fitness test on the knee injury which has sidelined the midfielder since October. If not, 19-year-old Mehdi Abeid, an Algeria Under-23 international midfielder, is expected to start in central midfield. Louise Taylor

Victory against Manchester City, hard on the heels of finishing first in their Champions League group, was an emphatic response to talk of another dressing-room revolt at Chelsea and André Villas-Boas will expect to maintain pressure on the leaders by beating a Wigan side that has won once at home in the league this season. David Luiz is available after suspension, though he would be fortunate to dislodge Branislav Ivanovic in defence, while Frank Lampard will hope his decisive penalty on Monday earns him a recall to the team. Andy Hunter

Having outmuscled Spurs to three points last weekend, confidence should be high within the Stoke squad as they head to Molineux. However, the players will be aware that their away form remains rotten; they have never won back-to-back Premier League fixtures outside of the Potteries and will find it tough to set that record straight on Saturday. Wolves have a good home record and are in dire need of points. They sit just above the relegation zone and play five games in the next two weeks. A win would ease the pressure ahead of a defining fortnight. Ian McCourt

Stewart Downing, who scored the only goal of the game in the corresponding fixture at the end of last season, can expect a hostile reception from Aston Villa supporters on his return to his former club. The England winger has still to score for a Liverpool side that have lost only once in their last 10 league matches. With Jay Spearing suspended and Steven Gerrard and Lucas Leiva sidelined, Jordan Henderson and Charlie Adam are set to continue in central midfield. Villa, meanwhile, will be without the suspended Gabriel Agbonlahor. Stuart James

These are the awkward days from which Manchester City had seemed to be exempted. Elimination from the Champions League had been likely for a little while, but events went sharply against them when they were denied a penalty at Chelsea and lost after holding the lead. If City are to win the Premier League, they can do so only by showing powers of recovery. The squad know a return to form is essential since Arsenal arrive as a side unbeaten in the league since 2 October and through to the last 16 of the Champions League. Kevin McCarra

These are strange times for Manchester United. On the face of it the club are in the midst of a mini-crisis; out of the Champions League and losing key players by the week, with the injured Nemanja Vidic and the ill Darren Fletcher unlikely to play again this campaign. However, should Sir Alex Ferguson's side triumph in west London on Sunday, they will return to the top of the Premier League for a few hours at least. Queens Park Rangers, with four defeats in their last six games, are definitely there for the taking. Sachin Nakrani

Martin O'Neill was reacquainted last week with the emotional turmoil that is life in a Premier League dugout and he now has another managerial staple: the bad off-field behaviour of players. He must decide whether to include Lee Cattermole and Nicklas Bendtner after their arrests on suspicion of causing criminal damage. Welcome back, Martin. O'Neill's presence has lifted Sunderland but they face a Tottenham team full of confidence despite their defeat at Stoke City, when they felt they were robbed. O'Neill must succeed where others have failed by blunting Spurs on home turf. David Hytner

On the face of it, this should be a perfect chance for Arsenal to return to winning ways. Aston Villa have not beaten Arsenal at home since 1998 and recent form suggests that run will be extended. They were insipid against Liverpool, when they suffered a third home defeat in four matches, and continue to have injury problems – Emile Heskey has joined Darren Bent and Chris Herd on the sidelines and James Collins is doubtful. Arsenal have their own selection issues – Alex Song is suspended and Johan Djourou is ruled out, meaning Ignasi Miquel could make his first league start for the club at full-back. Stuart James

With four clean sheets in their last six matches Swansea should be confident of increasing David Moyes's frustrations at Goodison Park, where the inevitable consequence of selling strikers and the club's most creative talents has cost Everton on a consistent basis. Everton have won only two of eight home matches this season, scoring just eight goals in the process, and with the prospect of Jack Rodwell and Diniyar Bilyaletdinov being sold from an already slim squad in January, they have to start taking maximum points at Goodison to avoid being dragged dangerously down towards the bottom of the table. Andy Hunter

Craven Cottage's reputation as a "good away" in the eyes of the United support has been tarnished of late, with the team taking only one point from the old stadium in the past three seasons. The jinx feels less likely to strike this time, given the way that Sir Alex Ferguson's team have built the best away record in the country. Unbeaten and seemingly impenetrable at the back, they travel with conviction. On the flipside, though, they are due a reverse and Martin Jol's Fulham project is coming together. This will be the London club's 32nd game of a season that began with a 3-0 win against Runavik in June. David Hytner

A win will guarantee Manchester City top the league at Christmas for the first time since 1929 and, after that amount of time, it would be impudent to point out they finished 13 points behind the champions, Sheffield Wednesday, that year. Roberto Mancini's team have dropped only two points at home throughout 2011 but Stoke could be tricky opponents, on a club-record run of four successive Premier League wins. The rewards, though, for the home side could well be significant: the team in first place at Christmas has gone on to win the league in five out of the last seven seasons. Daniel Taylor

West Bromwich are in the middle of an injury crisis which has forced them to recall loanees from Portsmouth, Doncaster and Brighton – the defender Gonzalo Jara, who missed his last game at the other Albion as he was in police custody for a driving offence. They travel to a club against which they have had little recent success – they have lost 53% of their last 19 league games against Newcastle (that's 10), winning only 5% (one) – but did come back from 3-0 down to grab a point on the last day of last season. Newcastle are without the suspended Yohan Cabaye, who misses his first league game of the season. Simon Burnton

From 16 Premier League outings so far in 2011-12 QPR average a point a game, Sunderland even less for their 14, so whoever can emerge from the four-match festive season jamboree in profit will feel some comfort as the race to avoid relegation starts in earnest in the new year. Sunderland have won only once on the road this season, QPR last enjoyed victory over four weeks ago and with only 33 goals between them a dour affair could well be in the offing. The last time these teams met was in the Championship in the 2006-07 season and Sunderland completed a double, winning both matches 2-1. Jamie Jackson

Wigan have fared surprisingly well in recent meetings here, taking a win and two draws from the last three, and have lost one in five against Liverpool overall, but Roberto Martínez feels that at present Kenny Dalglish's side offers a particularly stern test. "I got the opportunity to see them live against Aston Villa," he said. "They have quality all over and this is probably the strongest Liverpool we'll have faced in the last three or four years." More pertinent statistically is the fact that Liverpool have the best defence in the division this season, and Wigan the worst attack – one that will be further weakened if Hugo Rodallega fails a late fitness test. Simon Burnton

With Chelsea having opened talks over a deal for Gary Cahill, it is very possible this will be the defender's penultimate home match as a Bolton player. Along with his team-mates, the 26-year-old should be buoyed by the recent crucial victory at Blackburn and they will sensed that another three points can be gained against a Newcastle side who are losing form at an alarming rate. Alan Pardew's men have failed to win any of their last six fixtures and have become increasingly reliant on the prowess of top scorer Demba Ba. Sachin Nakrani

Chelsea, so encouraged by their display in the draw at White Hart Lane on Thursday, will seek a return to winning ways after successive away draws. These sides have already collided here this season in the Carling Cup, when the hosts prevailed on penalties despite being reduced to 10 following the dismissal of Alex. They have defensive concerns again with Branislav Ivanovic hamstrung and David Luiz a doubt. The visitors must recover from their home drubbing to Manchester United, though a difficult afternoon awaits. Dominic Fifield

Never before has this fixture been so much about the individuals involved. On one side there is Luis Suárez, playing at Anfield for the first time since receiving an eight-match ban from the Football Association, while on the other stands Steve Kean, the beleaguered Blackburn manager who arrives on Merseyside with his team in last place and their fans calling ever louder for him to be sacked. This should be another brutal afternoon for the Scot but a shock outcome cannot be ruled out given Liverpool's continuing wastefulness in front of goal. Sachin Nakrani

Wigan have taken points off Chelsea and Liverpool in their last two games but their record against Manchester United suggests this might be an afternoon when Roberto Martínez's team will be happy just to keep their respectability. The two sides have met only 13 times in their history, United have won them all and outscored their opponents 41 to four. Sir Alex Ferguson's team have 11 goals in their last three matches and the champions will see this as a chance to apply pressure on the leaders, Manchester City. Daniel Taylor

Darren Bent's return from Christmas shopper to frontline striker for this match could prove crucial for Alex McLeish. The Aston Villa manager's relationship with the club's fans remains fractured and could fully snap should the visitors suffer a third straight league loss here. Stoke's recent fine form was disrupted by a 3-0 loss at Manchester City, but that hardly counts as a setback. They will hope Peter Crouch can recover from illness in time to face his former club and, in the process, notch his 100th career league goal. Sachin Nakrani

Less than a month ago Martin O'Neill was expecting a quiet Christmas at home with his wife and two daughters. His installation as the Sunderland manager has changed that but O'Neill is not complaining about spending much of the festive period either supervising training or games. "I'm not a big eater and I don't like turkey," he said, "or rather, I don't like my wife's turkey." Everton have enjoyed a good record against Sunderland in recent seasons but after two wins in three games, O'Neill is quietly optimistic. "We seem to be up for the struggle," he said. "That's all I can ask for." Louise Taylor

West Bromwich Albion have the apparent comfort of a place in mid-table, but any sense of security has not come at The Hawthorns, where only seven of the 21 points have been collected. This fixture, though, may recall away contests since Roy Hodgson's team will probablyhave to concentrate at times on defending against the Premier League leaders. Manchester City won simply enough against Stoke on Wednesday, but the season has generally become more tense since their lead in the table was reduced to two points. The challenge now is to maintain the free-scoring style. Kevin McCarra

Arsène Wenger seemed almost affronted at the suggestion. The setting back of this game by 24 hours due to the latest outbreak of issues with London Underground allowed his Arsenal players the rare luxury of Christmas Day off. So the manager, presumably, could relax too? "You think about the next game, that's all," Wenger said. "On the 25th, you think Wolves. To do well against Wolves." Mick McCarthy would love a festive tonic at the Emirates but it is likely he would trade one for beating Bolton on New Year's Eve. David Hytner

A mark of Tottenham Hotspur's progress is that they could feel aggrieved only to draw with Chelsea last week, but they may soon be blunted by injuries. Rafael van der Vaart and Aaron Lennon have been ruled out while Jermain Defoe, Younès Kaboul and Ledley King are suffering. The latter pair's fitness could be key against the Norwich striker Grant Holt, whose brand of grazing menace demands to be taken seriously. With fixtures against Fulham, QPR and West Bromwich Albion coming up this could be a key period for Paul Lambert's side. James Callow

These teams have impressed following their promotion in the spring but, perhaps not surprisingly, currently find themselves hovering above the relegation zone. There must be a particularly strong sense of peril within the Queens Park Rangers ranks given the team have failed to win any of their last five fixtures and have now lost three in succession. Swansea can take heart from their formidable home record but may fear the threat of Heidar Helguson given the QPR striker has scored five goals in his last six appearances. Sachin Nakrani

Joey Barton wears a hooped shirt these days but his misdemeanours against Arsenal in the stripes of Newcastle have not been forgotten. Arsène Wenger brought up "the incident last season with Abou Diaby, Mr Phil Dowd as well", referring to Barton's awful tackle on the Arsenal player, which went unpunished, and Diaby's subsequent red card for retaliation while Barton's theatrics in August led to Gervinho's dismissal at St James' Park. Robin van Persie needs three goals to beat Alan Shearer's record Premier League haul in a calendar year. Wenger merely wants the three points. David Hytner

A second home match in five days brings with it a sense of dread and despair for Bolton. The hosts remain woeful at the Reebok Stadium, losing eight of their nine fixtures there this season, including the 2-0 loss to Newcastle on Boxing Day. They do not, then, face fellow strugglers in good spirits and must now also deal with the impending departure of Gary Cahill, with a fee for the defender having been agreed with Chelsea. It is likely he will play against a Wolves side buoyed by their recent 1-1 draw against Arsenal. Sachin Nakrani

Chelsea are virtually ruled out as potential champions this season, but it is in the Premier League that the London club must strive for improvement before the Champions League resumes. The flaws have been disconcerting since they contradict the usual assumption that the Stamford Bridge side will be efficient. You have to go down to Norwich in 11th to find a side with a worse home defensive record. Aston Villa, with their knack for drawing away games, will not be without hope even if they are generally regarded as being underachievers. Kevin McCarra

Blackburn head to Old Trafford lifted by the 1-1 draw they secured at Liverpool on Boxing Day but there can little sense of momentum being created within the ranks of the Premier League's bottom side. They are, after all, coming up against a team who have defeated their last two opponents 5-0 and know another win on Saturday will see them open a three-point gap at the top for 24 hours at least. There are more injuries for Sir Alex Ferguson to contend with, however, now Chris Smalling has been sidelined with tonsillitis. Sachin Nakrani

Paul Lambert said there was no shame in losing at home to Tottenham on Tuesday but he will feel differently if Norwich repeat the result against a Fulham side two points and two places worse off than his team. With the January sales about to open Martin Jol may not risk Bobby Zamora given the differences between the pair and who is doubtful anyway due to injury. Norwich have scored six more goals than Liverpool yet have a goal difference of minus six, one poorer than Fulham. So could this be a New Year's Eve goal glut? Jamie Jackson

Roberto Martínez will probably not dwell on the 5-0 defeat at Manchester United in which Conor Sammon was dismissed but has since had the red card rescinded. Before that thrashing, 18th-placed Wigan were enjoying a recovery. A win away at The Hawthorns and draws with Chelsea and Liverpool at home suggested a lightweight team had found some backbone. Stoke, ever a physical threat, will challenge that line of thinking but Tony Pulis's side have more than brawn in their arsenal and Wigan could be dismantled by neat wing play. Gregg Roughley

Eight wins from their past 10 games tells you how well Tottenham are playing. Harry Redknapp is wary of the threat posed by teams "scrapping for their lives" but it would be unfair to lump 14th-placed Swansea in with the strugglers. At home they have lost only to Manchester United, a narrow 1-0 defeat. Their expansive play may test a Spurs defence that is in constant flux due to injuries. Brendan Rodgers has been forced to recall his captain Garry Monk to replace the Spurs loanee Steven Caulker, who is ineligible. Gregg Roughley

BBC Swahili's flagship football programme, Ulimwengu wa Soka, will broadcast a live commentary from the Stadium of Light for the first time on Sunday. The majority of their audience are likely to be listening to this branch of the World Service in east Africa but it is a west African, the tricky, talented Benin forward Stephane Sessègnon, who will be trying to upset Manchester City's title hopes. Martin O'Neill had an unhappy six-month stint playing for City during the early 1980s and would regard taking a point from his old club as decent revenge. Louise Taylor

After the raucous celebrations at the end of the goalless draw against Manchester City, West Bromwich Albion supporters will be hoping for more than a point against Everton. Albion are on a good run, having taken seven points from a possible nine, but their record at The Hawthorns is poor. Youssouf Mulumbu is injured but James Morrison is fit and could play against an Everton team that sit one place below them. Everton will be without Marouane Fellaini and Landon Donovan is not eligible to play but Jack Rodwell should return. Stuart James

Michael Dawson is expected to make his first league appearance, having made a successful comeback in Saturday's 3-0 FA Cup defeat of Cheltenham Town. Harry Redknapp's pleasure at the return of Dawson could be tempered by the absence of Scott Parker, who is struggling with a knee problem, and he may well join Ledley King, William Gallas, Tom Huddlestone, Jermaine Jenas, Ledley King and Sandro on the sidelines. Everton have injury problems of their own, but they can take solace in an impressive recent record at White Hart Lane, having lost only one of their past five visits in the Premier League. Rich Flower

Two Republic of Ireland internationals should make their debuts for their respective new sides this Saturday – Robbie Keane for Aston Villa and Darron Gibson for Everton. Alex McLeish's side have failed to score in six of their last nine Premier League games and will hope Keane can correct this against the Toffees. David Moyes, meanwhile, will be hoping that Gibson can inspire his side after their recent defeats in the league to Tottenham Hotspur and Bolton as they look to start their traditional second-half-of-the season run of form. Ian McCourt

Rarely can a team embark on a home fixture against poor travellers with such trepidation. Blackburn may have beaten Manchester United recently but they remain wretched at Ewood Park, losing their most recent match there to Stoke, and given the continuing toxic atmosphere generated by the home support, cannot view this game, against a side who have won none of their last five away league games, as a certain chance for redemption. Christopher Samba's potential absence only adds to manager Steve Kean's woes. Sachin Nakrani

This fixture suddenly looms large and awkward for the hosts. Chelsea's home form has been too jittery for comfort, their propensity to implode when chasing victory having cost them three times already. The fragile Sunderland of early season might have offered some respite, but Martin O'Neill's revitalised charges represent a considerable threat. "He's had the right kind of impact there," said André Villas-Boas of his opposite number. "The team were low in motivation and self-belief, but they are now inspired." Steve Bruce's side won 3-0 here last season. In that respect, O'Neill has a hard act to follow. Louise Taylor

Liverpool have never lost a top-flight game at home to Stoke, a record lasting 48 matches, and will be confident of extending that sequence even without Luis Suárez, having finally located the net at Anfield and with the Carling Cup semi-final win at Manchester City behind them. This is the 50th game of Kenny Dalglish's second spell in charge – he has 26 wins, 12 draws and 11 losses so far – while Stoke, with Liverpool old boy Peter Crouch in form, have improved greatly on their travels and arrive at Anfield having lost only once in eight league games. Andy Hunter

Manchester United can spread a little anxiety. A win for Sir Alex Ferguson's side over Bolton would leave Manchester City leading the table purely on goal difference before they go to Wigan on Monday. Even so, that outcome against Bolton is far from sure. In 10 league matches at home United have been beaten twice and held to a draw once. Whether these visitors in particular can unsettle United is a matter of debate, but at least Owen Coyle's team took heart from overcoming Everton at Goodison. Whatever the sorrows at the Reebok, Bolton have a creditable record of four away wins in the Premier League this season. Kevin McCarra

Wolves, without a win in any competition since 4 December, look ill-equipped to break Tottenham's increasingly confident stride. Their strength is their wing play but Spurs' is stronger. Wolves did do the double over Harry Redknapp's team two seasons ago thanks to wasteful finishing by their opponents and, with Emmanuel Adebayor in profligate form recently, that seems their only chance of a repeat result. Scott Parker could return in midfield for the hosts after missing their past three games with a knee injury. Paul Doyle

The game between these sides at Carrow Road back in September seemed to bode badly for Norwich. The Canaries played perfectly well, but still lost and the season had started with four games without a win. It seemed to suggest they would go down in style, something Albion know about all too well. Since then, though, Norwich have picked up only four points fewer than Chelsea and the Baggies are in desperate need of a boost. They might not get it on Saturday, though, particularly with injury doubts surrounding six of their players. John Ashdown

There was a time when Mark Hughes came very close to becoming Newcastle United's manager but, instead, Kevin Keegan was chosen to replace the sacked Sam Allardyce. Four years on Alan Pardew leads the high flying Tynesiders and Hughes travels north for his first game in charge of a QPR side hovering one point above the relegation zone. While Pardew is probably delighted that Newcastle's former midfielder, and current Loftus Road captain, Joey Barton, is suspended, Hughes may be reassured to learn that Barton has urged team-mates dismayed by Neil Warnock's dismissal to "buy into" their new manager's philosophy. Louise Taylor

Whatever the outcome of this match it is unlikely to leave purists feeling short-changed. These, after all, are teams committed to an attractive, patient style of play with the only frustration for the respective supporters coming from the subsequent lack of goals, with the obvious exception of Robin van Persie. The last one Arsenal scored, of course, came from Thierry Henry against Leeds in what was a stunning return showing by the Frenchman. Despite the impact, he is likely to start on the bench again on Sunday. Swansea's defenders will surely hope he stays there. Sachin Nakrani

Out of the Champions League, the FA Cup and trailing in their Carling Cup semi-final: Manchester City's focus on securing the Premier League title is strengthening by the day. It will, then, concern Roberto Mancini's men if they have to begin this match sharing top spot with Manchester United and Tottenham, a scenario that is likely. Having not won away in the league since November, City's desire to break away from the chasing pack may end up relying greatly on a returning David Silva putting Wigan to the sword. Sachin Nakrani

Attention will be focused on two underachieving strikers. Liverpool's £35m Andy Carroll and Bolton's £4m David Ngog, who arrived from Anfield last summer, have much to prove. Ditto their two Glaswegian managers. While Owen Coyle is desperate to lift Bolton out of the relegation zone, Kenny Dalglish knows that seventh position, one place behind a comparatively low-budget Newcastle, spells mild disappointment on Merseyside. Coyle can only hope that, with Craig Bellamy unable to play two games in a week, Dalglish may opt to rest his catalytic Welsh forward ahead of next week's League Cup semi-final second leg against Manchester City. Louise Taylor

Everton have struggled to find the net but the visit of Blackburn could provide an opportunity to increase their goal tally – Rovers have yet to keep a clean sheet since they beat Bolton 1-0 in April. Blackburn's recent upturn in form has been partly due to the goals of former Everton striker Yakubu Ayegbeni. He will miss the game through suspension but Scott Dann could return from injury while Steve Kean may leave out Chris Samba, who has submitted a transfer request. For Everton, Jack Rodwell, Tony Hibbert and Sylvain Distin are still out. Tom Lutz

Fulham have been one of the steadiest Premier League clubs of the last few years, at least in terms of results. Yet this season they have been as unpredictable as anyone, capable of taking points off four of the top seven but also of surrendering feebly against 10-man Blackburn. They do at least have the best home record in the bottom half of the table – four wins and 15 points from 10 matches – the same as Newcastle in away games. This match may depend on how Newcastle cope without their African stars, especially if Yohan Cabaye does not pass a fitness test on an ankle injury. Rob Smyth

Norwich were unlucky to lose 3-1 when these sides met at Stamford Bridge in August, as they gave Chelsea a jarring test. Paul Lambert opted to play with a lone striker that day and Grant Holt gave John Terry such a mauling that it will be intriguing to see what happens if the Norwich manager decides to unleash both Holt and Steve Morison on the still brittle Chelsea defence at the same time. That would be quite a challenge for Gary Cahill, if André Villas-Boas decides to give his £7m new signing from Bolton a debut here. Chelsea, of course, will hope to keep play heading towards the other end and should have enough to prevail in a game that promises goals. Paul Doyle

Each of these relegation-threatened teams are desperate for a win as Mark Hughes's QPR (18th) entertain Roberto Martínez's bottom-placed side. Hughes's sole league outing as the new Hoops manager was the 1-0 loss at Newcastle last Sunday, meaning the club have gathered only two points from the last 27. The Welshman has so far brought in Henrique – work permit allowing – the first of what he hopes will be a clutch of new signings. Martínez is also talking about adding depth to his squad, but a fourth defeat from five outings will make it even harder for him to recruit. Jamie Jackson

On Boxing Day, West Bromwich Albion were ninth in the Premier League and looked set fair for a comfortable season but a run of three successive defeats has left them in 15th place and Roy Hodgson now admits his side are in a relegation battle. History suggests they will find little comfort this weekend: Stoke are unbeaten in 10 matches against Albion. For Stoke, Ryan Shotton and Rory Delap face fitness tests, while Paul Scharner could be missing for the visitors, for whom Jonas Olsson is likely to return from a calf injury. Tom Lutz

Martin O'Neill says Swansea's passing game is "great to see" in the Premier League and Sunderland will face a side high on confidence after the superb win over Arsenal last week. O'Neill may have his defence strengthened with the return of Wes Brown and Titus Bramble from injury, but in attack Fraizer Campbell is still short of match fitness. The Chelsea midfielder, Josh McEachran, arrived at the Liberty Stadium on loan earlier this week and is likely to start, while Gylfi Sigurdsson could also win a place in midfield after impressing as a substitute against Arsenal. Tom Lutz

Back in 1997 Robbie Keane made his league debut for Wolves – 14 years and £70m in transfer fees later he returns to Molineux in the colours of Aston Villa after joining on loan from LA Galaxy. He will not find a happy place – Wolves have gone seven league games without a win and lost to another West Midlands rival – Birmingham – in the FA Cup during the week. Roger Johnson, Matt Jarvis and Kevin Foley should all return for the home team while Keane may well start for Villa, who have Emile Heskey sidelined with an achilles injury. Tom Lutz

It must gall Arsenal that the season is not far beyond its halfway stage and there are title implications here only for their opponents. Arsène Wenger's side have lost back-to-back league matches for the second time this season and, 15 points off the top, their priority now is not to lose more ground in terms of the Champions League qualification places. United have the best away record in the league but this is also the chance for Arsenal to get August's 8-2 thrashing at Old Trafford out of their system, or at least soothe some of the wounds. Daniel Taylor

Manchester City are attempting to get closer to the Premier League title but in another sense they have been going backwards. Of late they have looked like last season's side, with that same caution. It is no longer so unusual to see the team go goalless. The dependence on David Silva for creativity is a flaw and he can look burdened. This is a match in which City may need some of their former exuberance. Tottenham were deflated by the home draw with Wolves and must try to demonstrate their persistence and quality at the Etihad Stadium. Kevin McCarra

These are challenging times for Arsène Wenger. Arsenal are still searching for their first Premier League win of the year and the transfer window has closed without any stellar signings arriving. Patience is wearing thin and some disgruntled supporters are planning to protest by putting bin liners over any empty seats at the Emirates Stadium on Saturday . Needless to say, Blackburn's visit is a must-win game. Blackburn, however, have picked up five points from their last three away matches, at Liverpool, Manchester United and Everton, and could prove to be awkward opponents. Stuart James

Manchester City have every cause to feel nervous. The leadership of the Premier League is no longer so reassuring when it is based solely on goal difference. A side that scored freely for a time was beaten 1-0 at Goodison Park in midweek. Some of the decline can be blamed on the loss of the Touré brothers to the Africa Cup of Nations, but City have also underperformed. At least they have the comfort of a perfect league record at home, with 11 wins. Fulham have recorded just one away victory in the league all season. Kevin McCarra

Things have started to look up recently for Bolton. An impressive 3-1 victory over Liverpool and a valuable point against Arsenal at the Reebok mean they now sit two points clear of the relegation zone. If they win at Carrow Road, it will be the first time in 11 months that they have gone three matches unbeaten in the league. But they face a stern test in the high-flying Canaries, whose manager, Paul Lambert, will be expecting a reaction from his side after Wednesday's 3-0 pummelling at the hands of Sunderland. Ian McCourt

It has been two months since Wolves' last league win and Mick McCarthy goes into this game aware that another loss would heighten calls for the club's chairman, Steve Morgan, to sack him. Queens Park Rangers have enjoyed a slight upturn in results since Mark Hughes replaced Neil Warnock at Loftus Road and have also been boosted by the arrival of several new players. Djibril Cissé, who scored on his QPR debut in the midweek draw with Aston Villa, and Bobby Zamora could start against a visiting defence that has wobbled recently. The best striker on the pitch could, however, be wearing gold, and if Wolves can get decent service to Steven Fletcher, then McCarthy's job should be safe for a while yet. Paul Doyle

The turnaround on Wearside since Martin O'Neill replaced Steve Bruce as Sunderland manager has been nothing short of miraculous. If the league had begun on the day O'Neill took over at Sunderland, the Black Cats would be top of the table with 19 points from a possible 27. Sunderland hammered Stoke 4-0 earlier in the season but Tony Pulis's side are a different prospect at home and Sunderland have failed to win there in their last four visits. This should be a real test for two teams who sit side by side in the table. Ian McCourt

West Bromwich Albion's poor form of late – they have picked up one win in their last six league games – has seen them slip down the table and their manager, Roy Hodgson, will be keen for his side to get back to winning ways. Swansea at home may just be the perfect place to start. Their easy-on-the-eye style has won the Welsh club many admirers but they have failed to take their impressive home form on the road, picking up only six points from 11 away matches – the worst away record in the league. Expect a close contest. Ian McCourt

Wigan are bottom of the Premier League and their last six league results read: L, L, L, L, D, L, with 18 goals conceded and five scored. The gap to the next side is three points and to safety it is five, so the time has almost certainly come for Roberto Martínez to start conjuring a consistent run of points. However, David Moyes's Everton, as ever, will not be easy. The previous time out, league leaders Manchester City were defeated by the Toffees, who may have returning loanee Steven Pienaar in their starting lineup. Jamie Jackson

This is second against fourth in the Premier League, a clash between two sides who have carved up the last seven titles between them, but somehow it does not feel like it. United have won eight of their last 10 fixtures in the league but are grinding out results in their pursuit of Manchester City. Chelsea, meanwhile, stumble and stutter in their attempt to hold on to the final Champions League spot. Neutrals must hope that at least one of these big beasts can rediscover their mojo come Sunday tea-time. John Ashdown

If Shay Given can expect a warm welcome on his return to Tyneside, Darren Bent should brace himself for hostility. As a one-time Sunderland forward Bent is not popular on Gallowgate, from where home fans will watch his intriguing duel with Fabricio Coloccini. Alan Pardew hopes to offer Papisss Demba Cissé, Newcastle's new signing from Freiburg, a debut, quite possibly alongside his Senegal strike partner Demba Ba. Signficantly, Pardew, who managed Bent at Charlton, is not discounting talk of Champions League qualification. Louise Taylor

Liverpool exude an air of conviction now that makes it hard to recall that they were defeated at Bolton recently. Those memories are all but erased following progress in the Carling Cup and FA Cup. However, Tottenham, 11 points better off in the league, may reintroduce some anxiety to Anfield. Their firepower has been greater than that of Kenny Dalglish's side. But Craig Bellamy and Dirk Kuyt have recently been at their best and Liverpool have not missed Luis Suárez too badly during a now completed suspension. Kevin McCarra

When these two sides met back in October at Loftus Road, goals from Heidar Helguson and Christopher Samba ensured that the points were shared. This time around both Mark Hughes and Steve Kean will be hoping for more than just a solitary point. Kean, undoubtedly, will be the more nervous of the two managers. His Blackburn side are just two points above bottom-placed Wigan and confidence cannot be high after last Saturday's 7-1 thumping at the hands of Arsenal. Not that Hughes is without his worries. QPR have won just one of their last 12 Premier League matches and, like Blackburn, are caught up in the battle against relegation. This will be a cagey affair but a win for either side could go a long way towards ensuring safety is achieved at the end of the season. Ian McCourt

Defeat is not an option for two sides rooted in the relegation zone. Bolton head into this encounter encouraged by recent results at home, most notably the 3-1 win against Liverpool on 21 January, and will feel they can hurt Wigan, who sit bottom having lost four of their last six games. Sachin Nakrani

The presence of Roman Abramovich at training this week has been a reminder to André Villas-Boas that his position as the Chelsea manager is under scrutiny. It will hardly ease his worries, then, to face an Everton side that beat Manchester City in their last home fixture. Sachin Nakrani

The midweek visit of Valencia is sure to be in the minds of Stoke's players but there is a real need for them to focus on the job in hand. They face Fulham having lost their last three matches in a row and aware their opponents have been strong at home in recent weeks. Sachin Nakrani

The availability of Luis Suárez adds a fresh ingredient to this simmering rivalry. The striker will face an away crowd and Patrice Evra for the first time since serving his ban for racially abusing the defender, if selected, and can prey on a Manchester United defence that has conceded two more goals this season than it did throughout the last campaign. Sir Alex Ferguson has fewer injury concerns than he did at Anfield for the recent FA Cup fourth-round tie, which his side lost 2-1, and his team will set a new club record of scoring in 43 successive league games should they beat José Reina. Andy Hunter

A match featuring arguably the Premier League's most exciting young wingers, James McClean and Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, can be regarded as a litmus test of Sunderland's short-term potential. Win and the Wearsiders will be just four points behind Arsenal with Europa League qualification suddenly achievable. Defeat, meanwhile, would suggest that eighth, the position they currently occupy, is probably the highest Sunderland can aspire to this season. Much may hinge on how tired Martin O'Neill's side are following last Wednesday's FA Cup replay victory at Middlesbrough and how distracted Arsène Wenger's team are by this Wednesday's Champions League trip to Milan. Louise Taylor

Promoted last summer, both these sides would have wanted little else but survival from this season but can now realistically aim for a top-half finish. They sit 10th and ninth respectively and have drawn many admirers for the pleasing nature of their approach play. Sachin Nakrani

The question to Harry Redknapp was almost an apologetic after-thought. Any injuries? Everyone laughed. How could the Tottenham manager be asked anything so trivial as to which players might be available when he was living in the eye of a storm? It rather summed up the problem facing his club. As Redknapp is pushed as the England manager-in-waiting – following the end of his crown court dramas – he and Tottenham must battle to retain their focus. Newcastle will prove a stern test. There was a cruel reaction in some quarters to Alan Pardew ruling himself out of the England jobbut he was only responding to a question and the work he has done at Newcastle has been estimable. Everyone outside the north-east keeps on predicting that the Toon will fall away but still they fly high in fifth and a win at White Hart Lane would advance their Champions League credentials. David Hytner

Manchester City have shown their firepower, but the effectiveness is not as great in away matches as that of Manchester United. Robert Mancini's team has 21 points on the road and might be optimistic about this trip since Aston Villa have recorded just three wins at home in the League. Nonetheless, Alex McLeish's team torments itself exactly because it keeps glimpsing its own potential. Of late they have been in contention at both Arsenal in the FA Cup and Newcastle in the League before losing. Villa's pent-up frustration could well make them dangerous to City. Kevin McCarra.

Roy Hodgson can reflect on his first year in charge of West Bromwich Albion with some satisfaction but his mood will darken should this Black County derby be lost to a side that sits just above the drop zone. Wolves should be buoyed by last week's 2-1 win at Loftus Road. Sachin Nakrani

All eyes will be on Chelsea's team-sheet ahead of this game to see if it contains starting places for Ashely Cole and Frank Lampard. The pair's absence from the side that started the defeat to Napoli stirred as much debate as the result itself, adding to the sense that André Villas-Boas, for all his defiance, remains in the midst of a crisis. Defeat to a Bolton team struggling for survival would put Chelsea's hopes of qualifying for next season's Champions League in serious danger and surely spell the end for their young manager. Sachin Nakrani

Until a Monday night meeting with Manchester United on 28 April that may well be the championship decider, Manchester City could be about to sail through a run of fixtures that starts with this visit of Blackburn. Yaya Touré is back from the Africa Cup of Nations and was imperious in the 4-0 Europa League win over Porto on Wednesday, while Carlos Tevez's instant return to first-team training following his apology suggests he may make the bench for next weekend's match with Bolton. Rovers are out of the drop zone, but on goal difference only, so this should be a regulation outing for City. Jamie Jackson

Terry Connor steps, blinking, into the spotlight after being named Wolves manager until May. Molineux's long-serving No2 could have wished for an alternative venue in which to commence his struggle against relegation. Quite apart from wanting to atone for a 5-0 defeat suffered at Tottenham two weeks ago, Newcastle welcome their key midfielders Cheik Tioté and Yohan Cabaye back from Africa Cup of Nations duty and suspension respectively. As if that was not sufficiently daunting, the Senegal strikers Demba Ba and Papiss Cissé are poised to lead Alan Pardew's attack. Louise Taylor

There would have been warmth between these sides during the era when they shared a stadium, but the sharing of a manager and striker in more recent times means this has become a west London derby with an edge. The Fulham supporters are likely to turn on Mark Hughes for leaving their club prior to this season and Bobby Zamora for doing the same during the last transfer window. The pair will need to ignore the jeers, however, and focus on helping Queens Park Rangers achieve a second win in 14 Premier League games. Sachin Nakrani

Albion may be eight points clear of the relegation zone but their wretched home record (only two wins at The Hawthorns all season) means they cannot afford to feel too comfortable. A visit from a Sunderland side that has been completely rejuvenated since the arrival of Martin O'Neill as manager in December is probably the last thing that the hosts need. There is some good news for Roy Hodgson's side, though: captain Chris Brunt is back in training after an ankle injury and should return within the next couple of weeks. Rich Flower

Sat in last place and without a win in their previous 10 Premier League matches on home soil, a sense of inevitability is starting to define Wigan's relegation prospects. In that regard their manager, Roberto Martínez, may look upon the opposition dugout with just a hint of frustration given he turned down the chance to take over at Aston Villa last summer. The club instead appointed Alex McLeish and may now be regretting that choice given the team currently sits three places above the drop zone. Sachin Nakrani

Rarely, in modern times, can Tottenham have travelled across the capital to confront their bitter rivals as favourites, but such is the apparent shift in the balance of power in north London. Spurs can move 13 points clear of Arsenal by repeating last year's success at the Emirates and Harry Redknapp's team will hope to exploit their hosts' brittle confidence. Arsène Wenger must rouse his troops after damaging defeats in the Champions League and FA Cup. Yet the suspicion lingers that this Arsenal team has one more big performance in them this term and the majority in the Emirates will be praying it is against the team looking down on them in the table. Dominic Fifield

It is a busy weekend, with a Carling Cup final as well as a north London derby, but this match at Carrow Road is a very serious matter in its own right for Manchester United. Manchester City lead the Premier League by two points from United and will expect to beat struggling Blackburn at home, but Sir Alex Ferguson's team should be tested at Carrow Road. A well-drilled Norwich, eighth in the table, can be obstinate and Paul Lambert has made such progress that his side ought, at the very least, to make life difficult for United. Kevin McCarra

The Britannia is bracing itself for a match between two teams battling to reach the top half of the table, separated only by goal difference. Having taken a four-strong bench to Valencia as Stoke were knocked out of the Europa League, Tony Pulis will have no excuses if the rested first-team regulars fail to fire against Swansea. Pulis's side haven't won at home since 2 January – while Swansea's form has been decidedly mixed since the victory over Arsenal. The return of midfielder Joe Allen from injury would be a boost to Brendan Rogers's side. Toby Moses

Things are not looking good for Aston Villa. Alex McLeish's side have only one win in their last seven games, Robbie Keane has returned to LA Galaxy and they may be without their top scorer, Darren Bent, for the rest of season. Still, facing Steve Kean's side they may not need Bent and Keane; Blackburn have not kept a clean sheet since April last year. Rovers were meek against Manchester City last week but as they showed at Manchester United, they are capable of beating those above them in the table and they will certainly fancy their chances against an out-of-form Villa. Ian McCourt

Last Sunday had a restorative effect on both clubs and Anfield should provide an accurate gauge of their newfound momentum. Arsenal produced the performance of the day in the north London derby while Liverpool savoured the achievement of ending their wait for a trophy in the Carling Cup final. Whether it heralds a new start in the Premier League, however, depends on games such as this. Liverpool are unbeaten in nine league games at home but seven have been drawn while Arsenal have lost six times on their league travels already. Something may have to give for either to state a convincing case for a top four finish. Andy Hunter

Manchester City continue the great game of applying pressure on Manchester United by hoping to defeat Owen Coyle's strugglers before the Reds travel to Tottenham for the late kick-off on Sunday. As only Carlos Tevez is unavailable, expect Roberto Mancini to select a strong XI that will fancy its chances of an easy afternoon against the league's second-bottom team. Bolton last won in the league on 21 January and have taken only a point from their last four outings so a minor miracle is required for them to gain anything here. Jamie Jackson

QPR's run-in is so wretched that if they do not get anything from this game, then their chances of avoiding relegation will suffer drastically. Their hopes will depend firstly on their ability to keep 11 players on the pitch, after the concession of dumb red cards undermined them in recent weeks. New signings Samba Diakité and Djibril Cissé are suspended but Mark Hughes can at least welcome back several injured players, as can David Moyes. Everton look better on paper and can play without pressure, making it difficult to see the home side achieving anything better than a draw. Paul Doyle

Norwich should have both their January arrivals available for the first time for their visit to the Britannia. The former Leeds captain Jonny Howson came through a reserve match unscathed after recovering from a knee injury and Ryan Bennett has returned from Peterborough, where he had been on loan since signing for Norwich during the last transfer window. Both could make the bench against a Stoke side that has struggled since the turn of the year, although they did end a run of four consecutive defeats by beating Swansea last week. Rich Flower

The assumption that André Villas-Boas's future as Chelsea manager hinges upon the outcome of their Champions League knockout tie against Napoli rather assumes the London club will not be embarrassed in any of their domestic fixtures ahead of the second leg, with a trip to The Hawthorns suddenly looking daunting. Albion have won their last two games by four-goal margins, seeing off Wolves' Mick McCarthy and inflicting rare damage on Sunderland's Martin O'Neill in the process. Chelsea have not lost here since 1979 – Villas-Boas must surely maintain that record to prolong his tenure. Dominic Fifield

Wigan probably need to win a minimum of four of their remaining Premier League fixtures to have a chance of staying up and at least a couple need to come this month, with Chelsea, Manchester United and Arsenal waiting at the start of April. Roberto Martínez spent several seasons with Swansea as a player and manager, but will put those memories to one side. "Those are memories I will never lose and I am extremely proud of them – I always hope the best for them but on Saturday I won't be able to share that feeling. "John Ashdown

Wolves fans will look back on August with fondness. Back then, with Mick McCarthy in charge, they strolled to a comfortable 2-0 win over a subdued Fulham side and on to the top of the Premier League. It was the first time that had been in such a position since August 1973. But how things have changed since then. A solitary point separates them from the relegation zone and they face a Fulham side that have only lost one of their last five league games. This will be a tough ask for Terry Connor's second game as caretaker manager. Ian McCourt

Events in Abidjan and Addis Ababa, if not those in Durban, will, unusually, have a bearing on the latest episode of an intensely parochial rivalry. Sunderland's key forward, Stephane Sessègnon, was delayed in Paris on Friday after missing a connection to Newcastle following Benin's international in Ethiopia but Cheik Tioté made his way back from a similar engagement with Ivory Coast. While Alan Pardew's key midfield enforcer may be tired, Newcastle's Senegal strikers, Papiss Cissé and Demba Ba, were significantly excused international duty in South Africa. Meanwhile Martin O'Neill, who turned 60 on Thursday, attends his first Tyne-Wear derby. Louise Taylor

Tottenham have an undistinguished record against Manchester United and will be without Scott Parker because of his red card in the 5-2 ordeal at Arsenal last weekend. Harry Redknapp's team have taken only eight points from their last six games but this still represents one of United's more challenging assignments between now and the end of the season. Wayne Rooney is back, having missed the previous two matches due to illness, and a draw would be reasonable for the champions before a run of seven games against teams from the bottom half of the table. Daniel Taylor

After last week's five-goal dismantling of Wolves, Martin Jol's side will be buoyant for the trip to Villa Park. What can brighten their mood more is the recent form of Alex McLeish's team – Villa have won just one of their last eight league matches and hover just three places above the relegation zone. Gabriel Agbonlahor has called for the fans to get behind the team but facing Fulham, who have won three in a row and who now sit eighth in the table, will be a tough test and there may be boos ringing in the Villa players' ears come full-time. Ian McCourt

A win in the early kick-off on Saturday could provide a long period of relaxation for either Owen Coyle or Mark Hughes; a loss and it will a long morale-sapping trip to the next match. Both of these sides are very much in the relegation mix – a slim goal margin keeps Bolton off the bottom while the same keeps QPR out of the drop zone. Rangers' record on the road might give Bolton some hope though – they have failed to keep a clean sheet in any of their last 10 away games and have taken just two points from the last seven of those matches. Ian McCourt

Stoke have not won a league game at Stamford Bridge since 1974 though, after much needed successive victories, they will be eager to test the state of Chelsea's nerves. Roberto Di Matteo will be welcomed raucously by the home support, even if the wounds are still raw from the dismissal of André Villas-Boas last weekend and his team's position feels precarious. Their ability to grind out victories will be scrutinised by Tony Pulis's men and, for all the interim coach's protestations that this game is the priority, the prospect of Wednesday's Champions League fixture with Napoli looms large. Dominic Fifield

In little over a month, Tottenham's focus has shifted from the title to holding on to third place amid an increasing threat from Arsenal. It is surely only a coincidence that Harry Redknapp's position has become uncertain in that period, as the performance against Manchester United indicated, but a third successive league defeat may alter that assessment. Everton, who have beaten Manchester City and Chelsea in their last two league games at home, represent an awkward challenge as David Moyes marks the approach of his tenth anniversary in charge against his potential future employers. Andy Hunter

As a former Newcastle striker, Liverpool's Andy Carroll can expect the hottest of Wearside receptions. While Carroll is likely to begin on the bench, the return of Steven Gerrard and Glen Johnson can only enhance a visiting side 10 points behind fourth placed Arsenal yet still talking about Champions League qualification. Kenny Dalglish's cause could aided here by the absence of Sunderland's Lee Cattermole and Stéphane Sessègnon – Martin O'Neill's key midfielder and forward – following their sendings-off during last Sunday's Tyne-Wear derby but Nicklas Bendtner might just give Jamie Carragher and company a tough afternoon. Louise Taylor

This match, together with the meeting of Bolton and QPR at the Reebok Stadium, will have a huge bearing on who survives in the top flight this season. Any three of the current bottom five could easily find themselves in the relegation zone come May so any points taken from their closest rivals will be crucial. Without a home win since 4 December, and with 12 goals conceded in their last three Premier League games, the Wolves caretaker manager, Terry Connor, was facing a difficult enough job even before an injury to Karl Henry and a bout of indiscipline from the captain, Roger Johnson. Connor remains confident he can keep the club in the division despite these setbacks. Only time will tell. Rich Flower

With only 11 games remaining the season now enters its must crucial period with United grateful that their rivals for the title – Manchester City – also kick off at 2pm on Sunday so there can be no possibility that they will start their match five points behind, as has been the recent occurrence. West Bromwich Albion turned over Chelsea last Saturday which got André Villas-Boas the sack, but despite Sir Alex Ferguson talking up the managerial qualities of his contemporary, Roy Hodgson, United should win this one by the odd goal at least. Jamie Jackson

After 27 games of the 2004-05 season – Norwich's last in the Premier League – the Canaries were 19th with 20 points and a goal difference of minus 26, a very similar situation to that which Wigan find themselves in now. Norwich were unable to survive that year and Wigan, runners-up in the second tier, replaced them in the top flight. If Roberto Martínez's team hope to produce a miracle that Saturday's hosts could not seven years ago, they will have to start by somehow conjuring a win against a side that is comfortable in mid-table and has been playing well, despite back-to-back defeats at the hands of Manchester United and Stoke respectively. Rich Flower

Roberto Mancini often plays down Manchester City's prospects of winning the Premier League title. That reflects the fact that the club is in with a reasonable chance of success, so much so that he wants to avoid placing too much emphasis on it. City are struggling to keep stress at bay and could not score in Thursday's Europa League defeat in Lisbon to Sporting. They will be glad to know that Swansea's previously impressive home form has waned of late, with just one Premier League win at the Liberty Stadium since 10 December. Kevin McCarra

Arsène Wenger has history with Alan Pardew and he is not inclined to hand out compliments to him. The pair clashed in November 2006 after Pardew's West Ham had scored a late winner against Arsenal. Yet Wenger prepared to welcome the Newcastle manager with a ringing endorsement of his team's style and "fantastic attitude", together with his business on the transfer market, name-checking the club's attacking and creative talents. Only a cynic would suggest that Wenger was encouraging Pardew to carry the game to Arsenal. The visitors have struggled on their three trips to the capital this season. David Hytner

As the final 10 games of the season get under way, Swansea arrive at Fulham sharing 36 points and the glow of near-definite safety. Martin Jol is gradually applying his blueprint to the Cottagers and can be pleased with the January signing of Pavel Pogrebnyak, who in four league starts has a handsome five goals. Good looks also characterise Swansea under Brendan Rodgers, whose blend of the pretty stuff with results – Manchester City and Arsenal have already been beaten by his men – marks him out as the next big thing. This could be a draw. Jamie Jackson

A look at the bottom of the Premier League table cannot help but provoke a closer inspection, because for all the doom that has attached itself to Wigan in recent weeks the club's hopes of avoiding relegation remain very much alive. Indeed, a victory in this match would see Roberto Martínez's side climb out of the bottom three for 24 hours at least. That will easier said than done, however, given the hosts have won only one of their last 13 games and face a West Bromwich Albion side that continues to impress this season. Sachin Nakrani

After four games without a win Newcastle are keen to get their Europa League qualification campaign back on track by exacting revenge on Norwich for December's 4-2 defeat at Carrow Road. Aware that Paul Lambert's side are yet to record a clean sheet on their Premier League travels, Alan Pardew must be tempted to field Demba Ba, Papiss Cissé and Hatem Ben Arfa in attacking tandem. Much may depend on whether Cheik Tioté is fit enough to anchor midfield, thereby protecting a recently vulnerable home defence. Louise Taylor

Manchester United can go four points clear at the top of the table and anything else would constitute a shock given Sir Alex Ferguson's team have the best away record in the league and are playing a side with only one win in their last 14 games. The two sides met three days after United were knocked out of the Champions League in December and it finished 4-1 in favour of Ferguson's men. They now meet three days after United's elimination from the Europa League and, for Wolves, it threatens to be a similar ordeal. They will, however, have the fresher legs. Daniel Taylor

These are joyously familiar times for Arsenal. Six consecutive wins have enabled the club to reestablish themselves in a position above Tottenham in the Premier League and they will be aware the gap to their north London rivals will increase to four points should Aston Villa be defeated on Saturday afternoon and, earlier in the day, Harry Redknapp's side suffer defeat at Stamford Bridge. The visitors have already lost twice to Arsenal this season but should take some confidence from last week's dramatic win over Fulham. Sachin Nakrani

After everything that has happened over the last week, Bolton must return to the business of trying to win a crucial match near the bottom of the table. But it will be difficult. Owen Coyle's players must have used up an enormous amount of emotional energy and they are facing a Blackburn side who have won successive matches for the first time this season. A third straight victory for Steve Kean's team would put them seven points clear of their Lancashire rivals. Bolton, however, would love nothing more than to dedicate a win to Fabrice Muamba, 250 miles away in the intensive care unit of the London Chest Hospital. Daniel Taylor

Where there is a way to snatch despair from the jaws of triumph, Tottenham have frequently found it over the years. Remember the "dodgy" lasagne of 2006? They would surpass themselves, though, if they were to miss out on Europe's elite competition this time. Harry Redknapp's squad are hardier and more talented than previous vintages at the club yet the jitters would intensify if they lost here, which is what Tottenham teams tend to do at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea are equally desperate for a positive result and their margins for error are even slimmer than their opponents'. David Hytner

Prior to the start of the season Liverpool supporters would have thought it absurd that, come the spring, their team would be only one place and three points ahead of Swansea. That, however, is the situation they find themselves in following the midweek collapse at Queens Park Rangers, a result which all but crushed any faint hope Kenny Dalglish's side had of returning to the Champions League next season. Wigan, undefeated in their last four matches against the hosts, remain focused on retaining their top-flight status. Sachin Nakrani

Both clubs have lost three of their last four games but their relative league positions mean that these results have produced differing reactions. Norwich look a better side than recent form suggests and remain comfortable in mid-table. Wolves, conversely, have been abysmal since the appointment of Terry Connor as interim manager and seem doomed to relegation unless they can somehow produce a remarkable turnaround. The only hope the visiting fans can cling to is that after the nadir of a 5-0 home defeat by Manchester United last week, surely things cannot get any worse? Rich Flower

A return to the Premier League's summit awaits Manchester City should they avoid defeat in this game. Roberto Mancini's side may only stay there until Monday night but it will do their confidence no harm to look down on their rivals in what is becoming an increasingly heated title race. Sir Alex Ferguson mocked his counterpart on Friday for recalling Carlos Tevez from his "five-month holiday" but given that he set up Samir Nasri's winning goal against Chelsea, the decision already appears to have been the right one. Sachin Nakrani

Mark Hughes has warned his Queens Park Rangers players that Wednesday's comeback win against Liverpool will count for nothing if they fail to perform at the Stadium of Light. "We can't allow that momentum and uplifting feeling to dissipate," said Hughes, who will be without the injured Armand Traoré but may have Clint Hill available again. Sunderland, who face Everton in the FA Cup on Tuesday, have Stéphane Sessègnon back from suspension but Kieran Richardson misses out and John O'Shea will have a late fitness test. Marcus Christenson

Everton have won 10 and lost none of their 14 previous meetings with Swansea, although it is perhaps wise not to read too much into that: only December's 1-0 victory at Goodison Park was within the last 29 years. Less promising for the visitors is the fact that they have not scored in their last two matches, while Swansea have not conceded in three and will have Ashley Williams available again after illness kept him out against Fulham last week. "We will have to make sure we try to stop the rhythm of their play," says David Moyes. Simon Burnton

A win for Newcastle would see them reach 50 points in the top flight for the first time since the 2005-06 campaign, which was also the last time they qualified for European competition – albeit through the Intertoto Cup. While Alan Pardew's side may have harboured loftier ambitions earlier this season, a Champions League place now looks beyond them. But the battle for fifth, and a spot in the Europa League play-offs, remains very much alive. With Chelsea, their main rivals, facing a tricky game with Tottenham, Newcastle will look to take advantage at The Hawthorns. Rich Flower

Whether it is to return to the summit or extend the gap on Manchester City, United know there can be no slip-up on Monday night against a Fulham side that has won only twice on the road in the league this season. The pressure of playing after City has not fazed the champions of late and, now the mind games have been declared officially open by Sir Alex Ferguson, he will have a very strong looking squad available with Phil Jones, Chris Smalling, Tom Cleverley, Paul Pogba and Fábio da Silva all featuring for the reserves in midweek. Andy Hunter

While Aston Villa are not quite in relegation trouble – yet – they are in the middle of a miserable run of form, picking up four points from their last seven games and failing to record a single shot on target in their 3-0 defeat at Arsenal last Saturday. They will have to do without Alan Hutton while Ciaran Clark is still recovering from a knee problem. Chelsea have no new injury concerns and Salomon Kalou could keep his place ahead of Daniel Sturridge after scoring the winner against Benfica in the Champions League earlier this week. Tom Lutz

West Bromwich Albion were outplayed by Newcastle at The Hawthorns last week and James Morrison sustained a knee injury that is likely to rule him out for the rest of the season. Paul Scharner and Graham Dorrans are the candidates to take his place in midfield, while the captain, Chris Brunt, is available again after a bout of tonsillitis. If Everton win they could rise above Liverpool into seventh place and Steven Pienaar returns to David Moyes' squad after being cup-tied for Tuesday's FA Cup replay victory over Sunderland. Tom Lutz

Norwich last came to Craven Cottage on the final day of the 2004-05 season, knowing that a win could keep them in the top flight. Unfortunately for the visitors, they produced a shambolic performance, lost 6-0 and were relegated, beginning a period of decline that eventually saw them drop as low as the third tier. The Canaries are back now, though, and look far better equipped to survive this time, having arrested a recent mini-slump in form with an easy win over Wolves. Paul Lambert's side will be unsure of what to expect from an inconsistent Fulham side, who have followed three wins with three defeats. Rich Flower

Manchester City may no longer be in command of their own fate in the Premier League, but they now have the opportunity to put pressure on their rivals. Should City continue their perfect home record in the league, they will lead the table on goal difference, with United returning to action at Ewood Park on Monday. All the same, beating Sunderland will not be elementary, even if Martin O'Neill had his first serious set-back when his side was beaten 2-0 at home by Everton in the FA Cup sixth-round replay on Tuesday night. Kevin McCarra

Queens Park Rangers have won fewer league games all season than Arsenal have in their recent seven-match hot streak. Mark Hughes will be without his French striker Djibril Cissé, who is beginning a four-match ban for another red card, but the Welshman can recall the club's top scorer Heidar Helguson after a lengthy knee injury. Helguson's praiseworthy tally of nine goals in 18 appearances is eclipsed by Robin van Persie's haul of 37 in 45 for Arsenal. A point could lift Rangers out of the drop zone ahead of a testing trip to Old Trafford, though Laurent Koscielny's return to Arsenal's defence should bolster the Gunners' bid for a third successive clean sheet. Jonny Weeks

Roberto Martínez's team avoided the drop on the final day of last season at Stoke and sense a dramatic escape once more after a run of one defeat in seven games. Wigan's form was improving even before last week's victory at Liverpool, "a historic win" according to their manager, and they are now only a point off safety despite a dreadful return of one home win all season. Correcting that glaring weakness is the key to survival but, having frustrated Manchester City last weekend, Stoke will be strengthened by the return of Ricardo Fuller from suspension and Jonathan Woodgate from injury. Andy Hunter

Bolton's focus returns to the league following their FA Cup defeat to Tottenham, and they travel to Wolves on Saturday knowing that a win would not only keep them out of the relegation zone, but also consign Wolves to their seventh consecutive home loss and another week at the foot of the table. Darren Pratley misses the game after suffering a gashed leg at White Hart Lane, but the rest of the Bolton squad is likely to remain unchanged. Wolves look set to recall a host of players, with Ronald Zubar returning from suspension, and Karl Henry, Stephen Hunt and Michael Kightly all available for selection after spells on the sidelines. Tom Lutz

Andy Carroll returns to Tyneside for the first time following his £35m move in January last year. Charlie Adam looks likely to miss the rest of Liverpool's season after picking up a knee injury against QPR last week, while Craig Bellamy, Daniel Agger and Glen Johnson are also doubtful. Newcastle's captain, Fabricio Coloccini, is a definite absentee, with James Perch expected to replace the Argentinian in central defence. Papiss Cissé is set to start in attack despite appearing to pick up a knock at West Bromwich Albion last Sunday. Charlie Scott

This should be a mouth-watering match though, at present, Tottenham would gleefully accept even the scrappiest success to reignite their league campaign. Harry Redknapp will point to the defeat of Bolton in the FA Cup, and the second-half performance at Chelsea last Saturday, as evidence that form is creeping back into his charges, but theirs is a five-match winless streak in the Premier League and they could go into this fixture six points adrift of Arsenal and only two ahead of Chelsea and Newcastle. Swansea, their manager Brendan Rodgers admired at White Hart Lane, will hope to reproduce their display in victory at Fulham rather than that of the home defeat to Everton last week. Dominic Fifield

If Manchester United seem well-placed to retain the title it has much to do with the solidity shown on hostile territory in the Premier League. A failure at Newcastle United is their sole loss in 15 away games so far. In that regard, Sir Alex Ferguson's team have been much superior to Roberto Mancini's Manchester City. Each fixture, however, has its own context and Blackburn Rovers will be spurred on by the knowledge that, despite an upturn in form since Christmas, just three points separate them from the relegation places. Kevin McCarra

Events off the field have deflected attention from Bolton's recent encouraging run of form. Owen Coyle's side have won their last three matches in a row and, as such, find themselves two places and one point above the relegation zone.
