Confidence can also be taken from Bolton's much-improved home form; they have lost only one of their last six at the Reebok Stadium, and will feel they can extend that sequence against visitors sat comfortably in mid-table and who may be without striking sensation Pavel Pogrebnyak. Sachin Nakrani

Roberto Di Matteo may have reinvigorated Chelsea but there is still a major doubt over their ability to sustain improved performance on three fronts. Looming Champions League and FA Cup semi-finals may mean that this is an ideal time for Wigan to arrive at Stamford Bridge – with the form that Roberto Martínez's men have been in recently, there is a strong chance of the visitors increasing their survival prospects by taking the points. Wigan will be aided by having an almost fully fit squad to pick from, with Mohamed Diamé and Hugo Rodallega the only doubts. Paul Doyle

It is hard to know who needs to win this match more. Aston Villa sit just five points above the relegation zone and having lost their last two fixtures, must fear that they could yet slide into deep trouble. They face a side, however, who have lost six of their last seven games and so close to an FA Cup semi-final with Everton, desperately need to start building some positive momentum. Kenny Dalglish's side are without José Reina following his red card at Newcastle last week but simply cannot afford to feel sorry for themselves. Sachin Nakrani

The Norwich City manager, Paul Lambert, was very complimentary when he spoke ahead of Saturday's match. "Everton are a really top side and have some really fantastic players, and since January they brought in a couple of lads to give them a hand. Their form at this minute is very, very good," he said. Secretly, Lambert may well be hoping that the visitors are distracted by their FA Cup semi-final with Liverpool. The Canaries have a tough looking run-in and although they probably have enough points to banish any lingering relegation worries, a win here would still be very welcome. Rich Flower

When you have lost your last five matches in a row and conceded 17 goals in the process the last thing you need is a match against Stoke. That, however, is what awaits Wolves, bottom of the table, six points from safety and, under the control of the seemingly overwhelmed Terry Connor, an increasingly safe bet for relegation. The visitors can take hope from Stoke's run of four games without a win but given their most recent contest on home turf was the 1-1 draw with Manchester City, a shock result does not appear likely. Sachin Nakrani

Michael Turner grew up supporting Tottenham but on Saturday the Sunderland centre-half's job is to prevent Harry Redknapp's side from scoring the goals which would reinforce their quest for Champions League qualification. With Gareth Bale back on top form and Aaron Lennon fit again Tottenham look renascent and Turner watched nervously as Redknapp's players ended a five-game run without a win at Swansea's expense last week. "It's going to be a hugely tough match," he said. "We'll have to defend well to get anything out of it – but it should be an interesting contest." Louise Taylor

Defeat to Bolton in a match overshadowed by Fabrice Muamba's heart scare and then to Manchester United on a night when the champions took a big step toward holding on to their crown has somewhat masked Blackburn's loss of form in recent weeks. Steve Kean's side are now back in the relegation zone on goal difference and need their creative talents, most notably top-scorer Yakubu, to turn good displays into points. West Bromwich Albion, without a win in their last four games, could well prove to be pushovers. Sachin Nakrani

By Roberto Mancini's own admission, Manchester City will wave a white flag in the title race if they lose against the team directly below them and Manchester United beat QPR in the early kick-off. City have won one of their last four games and it was rare to see them look so anaemic as last weekend at Sunderland. A vast improvement is needed and it will help that Sergio Agüero, Joleon Lescott and Samir Nasri, returning to his former club, are back. Arsenal have considerable requirements of their own, however, in the pursuit of a Champions League place and have not lost at home to City in a league fixture since 1975. Daniel Taylor

The formula is simple for Manchester United: defeat Queens Park Rangers and the champions take an eight-point lead over Manchester City, who kick off later in the afternoon at Arsenal, with only six games remaining for Sir Alex Ferguson's men. Nani should be back to strengthen a squad against Mark Hughes's relegation-haunted team – the spectre the Welshman hopes will help propel Rangers to what would be an invaluable victory, and one that would again turn this season's title race on its head. This seems rather unlikely, though. Jamie Jackson

There has been a perverse type of stubbornness to Roberto Mancini. He was still insistent that Manchester City could not win the title despite Manchester United's defeat at Wigan. If it was intended to relieve the pressure, it had the side effect of undervaluing a costly team. Mancini's wish seems to be for City to lurk in the shadows if that is feasible with the likes of Mario Balotelli and Carlos Tevez in his squad. The realist in him also knows how hard it could be to beat Paul Lambert's well-drilled Norwich at Carrow Road. Kevin McCarra

On Sunday 4 December, Sunderland lost 2-1 at Wolves. Steve Bruce had just been sacked, the Wearsiders stood 17th and many neutrals would have tipped them for relegation ahead of Mick McCarthy's 15th-placed side. Since then though, Martin O'Neill has presided over the collection of 31 points. Wolves have accrued a mere eight, while replacing McCarthy with Terry Connor along the way. Connor – who boasts one point from a possible 24 since taking charge – hopes to prevent his Championship-bound side from recording an eighth straight defeat. Louise Taylor

Of late, Brendan Rodgers's side look a shade of the team whose stylish play has earned plaudits and praise in abundance this season. They have lost their past four games and conceded 10 goals in the process. That form should give Blackburn hope of taking three points, except that Steve Kean's side have also lost their last four and also conceded 10. Rovers got the better of Swansea earlier in the season thanks to four goals from Yakubu Ayegbeni; if he can repeat that performance, it will surely be the home side who slip to a fifth defeat. Ian McCourt

A hat-trick of home wins has Loftus Road finally warming to Mark Hughes, but with only two more games to host this season the Welshman will know they may also need to pick up something away to avoid relegation. Given that their other two remaining trips are to Chelsea and Manchester City this looks the best chance of an away point or three, and Hughes has Shaun Derry available after suspension to aid his cause. Roy Hodgson will tell his Albion players they are not completely safe yet, but one more win and they will be. Paul Chronnell

The excellent run of results for Manchester United came to a halt with the 1-0 loss at the DW Stadium, but something was due to go wrong. Although the consistency had been outstanding, it still seemed remarkable that Sir Alex Ferguson could get so much out of the squad. European results demonstrated the limitations of Ferguson's resources and, against Wigan, the absence of Paul Scholes, with all his knowhow, was a great handicap. Nonetheless, Villa have won only three league games away from home this season. Kevin McCarra

Arsène Wenger continues to preach concentration and discipline with manic zeal; chalk each game off as it comes. Arsenal are nearly there and third place would taste all the sweeter given the turmoil of their season. The questions will remain as to whether progress has been made – the club's trophy drought seems to have been temporarily overlooked – but a powerful finish would fire optimism for the future. The job in hand is no foregone conclusion and those who saw Wigan Athletic scare Chelsea would not have been surprised at their win over Manchester United. David Hytner

Only now are we seeing the true genius of Roman Abramovich. Appoint a manager with an impossible brief, see him struggle and player resentment fester; then remove him at the business end of the season and watch the players recoil to devastating effect. André Villas-Boas or Roberto Di Matteo, it is all about the players in SW6 and they have one foot in the Champions League final and both in the FA Cup final. For their next trick, they intend to beat Arsenal to set up a fourth-placed finish. Chelsea's momentum is irresistible. The owner's masterplan is coming together. David Hytner

Martin O'Neill returns to Aston Villa for the first time for what promises to be a tense and highly-charged occasion. It will be intriguing to see what sort of reception O'Neill receives at the club where he secured three successive top-six finishes before walking out five days before the start of last season. Villa, for a variety of reasons, have been in a mess ever since. They go into the first of two home games in four days six points above the relegation zone. Sunderland have no such concerns but have failed to win in four matches. Stuart James

Turmoil has well and truly returned to Ewood Park, with Blackburn supporters planning to march in protest to the stadium ahead of this encounter having witnessed their side lose their last five matches in a row, leaving them three points into the relegation zone with four league fixtures to play. Steve Kean believes his side need to win two and draw one of those games to remain in the Premier League and will no doubt be seeking all three points against a side who were thrashed 6-1 by Manchester City in their last match. Sachin Nakrani

For Bolton, the hard work starts here. Due to a variety of reasons, Owen Coyle's side have played only three league games in the past 28 days but, starting today, they have six in little over three weeks which will decide their top-flight future. None of them look as winnable as this one against a Swansea side for whom you could say the hard work stops here. Brendan Rodgers' men have achieved so much this season, but of late have looked ready to hit the beach and return in August. Bolton may be in the Championship by then. Paul Chronnell

The enigma that is Wigan Athletic has been elevated to the mainstream this week after successive victories over Manchester United and Arsenal lifted them clear of the relegation zone. But this is Wigan, it is always necessary to expect the unexpected. The Latics were beaten 2-0 at home by Fulham earlier this season and Roberto Martínez is acutely aware they are capable of losing again and ending up straight back in trouble, especially as the hosts should have their forwards Pavel Pogrebnyak and Andrew Johnson back. Paul Chronnell

Momentum is an overused word in football these days but, whatever name it goes by, a run of five successive victories has got everybody believing Alan Pardew's side can prise a top-four spot from one of London's big three. The possible return of the midfielder Cheick Tioté will help, and victory over Stoke would all but secure at least Europa League football for next season. Tony Pulis is well positioned to advise on whether that is a good or bad thing, as his Stoke side limp to the finish line following an exhaustive campaign. Paul Chronnell

By the time this game kicks off on Saturday evening, both clubs could be facing their worst-case scenarios for the season's end – QPR will be back in the relegation places if Bolton beat Swansea, while Tottenham could be as low as sixth if Chelsea and Newcastle prosper. The return of Djibril Cissé from suspension could be key to Rangers continuing their run of three successive home victories. Harry Redknapp believes four wins from Spurs' remaining five games will secure a top-four spot, but their last away league win was in December. Paul Chronnell

Carling Cup success did not improve Liverpool in the Premier League, with five of their next six games ending in defeat, but there is no excuse for coasting following their latest Wembley win. Team places for the FA Cup final are at stake over the next three matches, the club's owners are in town, and Kenny Dalglish is demanding momentum ahead of the meeting with Chelsea as Liverpool aim to overtake Everton in the table. Anfield knows from painful experience that patience is required with a Roy Hodgson team and Albion boast as many away wins this season as Chelsea and Tottenham. Andy Hunter

Beyond this encounter is the 162nd Manchester derby on 30 April, and Sir Alex Ferguson will tell his men that if they beat Everton then a 20th championship could be clinched at the Etihad Stadium whatever Manchester City do later on Sunday afternoon at Wolverhampton Wanderers. This is the dream scenario – one David Moyes hopes he can prevent, though being able to pick his men up after the despair of being knocked out of the FA Cup semi-final at Wembley by Liverpool may prove too tough a task even for his man-management skills. Jamie Jackson

Manchester City's goal difference of 58 is the highest for 24 years in England's top flight at this point in the programme. It could well rise appreciably at Molineux on Sunday. To general surprise, Wolves took a scoreless draw at Sunderland in their last outing, but there is still a chance that a defeat here will see them relegated from the Premier League. If there is any concern in City's minds it will lie in the fact that Terry Connor's side could be liberated by the realisation that this is a high-profile occasion in which they have little to lose. Kevin McCarra

Everton's display at Old Trafford last week showed the side has not downed tools following their defeat to Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-finals and, indeed, the very real prospect of finishing above their Merseyside rivals for a second time in eight seasons is sure to keep them motivated until the end of the campaign. They will fancy their chances of defeating Fulham given the London club has not even gained a point at Goodison Park since 1959 but should also be weary of opponents who are unbeaten in their last four matches. Sachin Nakrani

Victory for the hosts would draw Norwich level on points with Liverpool, which speaks volumes for how much each of these clubs has confounded expectations this season. Grant Holt has scored more league goals than Luis Suárez and Andy Carroll combined and, as the forward fulcrum of Paul Lambert's efficient team, will be confident of adding to his haul against a Liverpool side who have conceded in all but one of their last 11 games. Norwich do not keep many clean sheets either but Liverpool's curiously wayward finishing means a home victory could be on the cards. Paul Doyle

Chelsea's progression to the Champions League final has increased the prospect of the team that finishes fourth in the Premier League this season missing out on playing in Europe's elite competition next year. Landing third spot is critical, therefore, a position currently held by Arsenal. Arsène Wenger's side have failed to win either of their last two games and with Newcastle, Tottenham, and Chelsea, likely to win this weekend, they cannot afford a slip-up in a fixture they have found tough going in recent seasons. Sachin Nakrani

While Sunderland fans contend with nagging fears that the Football Association may yet choose Martin O'Neill rather than Harry Redknapp or Roy Hodgson as the next England manager, relegation avoidance continues to dominate Bolton's agenda. Owen Coyle's side will aim to build on Tuesday's win at Aston Villa but O'Neill, who may offer David Meyler a rare start in midfield, are anxious to end a run of four games without a goal. Much may depend on how Bolton's forwards cope against Michael Turner and Matt Kilgallon. Louise Taylor

It is hard to know exactly what the Wolves owner, Steve Morgan, was thinking when he jettisoned Mick McCarthy in February but you can only presume it was not to be relegated in abject misery before the end of April. Terry Connor's tenure has realised just two points from 10 games and the irony would be considerable if he finally gets a first win now. Swansea, with only one victory in their last six, have been in holiday mode for some time, but keeping hold of the coveted Brendan Rodgers this summer is now their main concern. Paul Chronnell

Tuesday night's home defeat against Bolton means that Aston Villa go into this derby only three points clear of the relegation zone and with Alex McLeish's position looking untenable. The Villa manager, who faced vitriolic abuse at the end of the Bolton game, will at least be able to call on some senior players at The Hawthorns, with Gabriel Agbonlahor, Richard Dunne and James Collins all set to start. Albion, who should be full of confidence on the back of last Sunday's win at Anfield, have their eyes on a top-10 finish. Stuart James

Roberto Martínez warned his players that the job was not done after the wins over Manchester United and Arsenal seemed to ease their relegation fears and defeat at Fulham, coupled with all their rivals picking up points since, has proved him right. Martínez may have to do without Franco Di Santo but Hugo Rodallega could return in his place. Newcastle have a few injury concerns and the knowledge that victory will keep them in fourth place ahead of what is already looking like a pivotal midweek trip to Stamford Bridge. Paul Chronnell

The pre-match handshake may no longer be an issue, but John Terry will still draw the focus as Chelsea return to Premier League duties with a derby to get the juices flowing. Victory will be imperative if hope of securing a place in the top four is to be maintained, though tweaked hamstrings and general fatigue may influence Roberto Di Matteo's selection. QPR have concerns at the other end but did beat Chelsea's nine men in that infamous meeting back in October. Away form has deserted them over recent months and they have not won in the league at Stamford Bridge since 1983. Victory would secure them a first double over local rivals in 37 years. Dominic Fifield

In theory, Tottenham's prospects are in reasonable shape since they are just three points away from fourth place. The trouble, of course, is the decline in their form since Fabio Capello's resignation and the speculation suggesting Harry Redknapp could be the next Englanad manager. If there is any comfort, it lies in that fact the remaining fixtures see them face this week's opponents Blackburn, ahead of games with Bolton, Aston Villa and Fulham. While Fulham are ninth, the others are all struggling at the wrong end of the table. Kevin McCarra

You may have heard there is a game on Monday night. By all accounts, this is the most significant Manchester derby that has ever been staged, not just for what it means in this season's title race but also the next phase of their rivalry. United have a three-point lead but City have the superior goal difference so a win would return them to the top of the league, with only two games to go. Roberto Mancini's team have dropped only two points at home all season while United have the best away record in the division. Something has to give. Daniel Taylor

The chase for third place remains in Arsenal's hands, but with Tottenham and Newcastle in close pursuit there is no room for error. Arsène Wenger's team, without a win in three games, have laboured since Mikel Arteta's injury removed the metronome which keeps everything ticking, and the responsibility to drag them over the line rests with a tired Robin van Persie. With Norwich having metaphorically laid out the beach towels, this is a good opportunity to grab a much needed victory. Norwich have conceded 11 goals in their last three matches, including hat-tricks for Carlos Tevez and Luis Suárez. Van Persie will be hoping the Canaries defence continues to be accommodating. Amy Lawrence

This is a huge game for both clubs. Aston Villa, who have won only once at home since November, are only three points clear of the relegation zone while Spurs are right back in contention for a Champions League place after back-to-back victories. Scott Parker is fit again after recovering from an ankle injury and is expected to start for Spurs on an afternoon when Alex McLeish has vowed to keep a low profile and remain in his dugout in the hope that it will encourage Villa fans to focus on the team rather than on him. Stuart James

It is not often you get to see the England manager in charge of a club side, and the irony will not be lost on Roy Hodgson that he will sit in the away dugout from which Harry Redknapp instructed his Tottenham team to a 4-1 victory on Wednesday night. So how will Hodgson compare to his vanquished foe? He might not care too much as Albion have little to play for, which cannot be said of a Bolton team whose top-flight tenure is hanging by an ever-weakening thread. A distracted Hodgson and Albion could prove ideal opposition. Paul Chronnell

Both Fulham and Sunderland will be looking for the three points that would virtually guarantee a top-10 finish but the form of these teams could not be more different. The hosts have taken 13 points from their last six Premier League games, including a first ever win at Anfield in midweek. By contrast, Martin O'Neill's side have not had a victory since 24 March and are playing very much like a side with one eye on their summer holidays. For the visitors, John O'Shea and Nicklas Bendtner face late fitness tests on their respective injuries. Rich Flower

The tension may be at its peak well before Manchester United take the field. Their hopes rest with Manchester City, who lead the Premier League on goal difference, faltering at Newcastle United, who shocked Chelsea by winning 2-0 at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday night. Such an outcome would see Old Trafford brimming with euphoria before the match there has even begun. Swansea's season has been excellent, but their form has faded of late, with just a single victory for Brendan Rodgers' side in the last seven matches. Kevin McCarra

The sums are simple for Manchester City now: win their last two games and the title is all but guaranteed. It is a difficult assignment though, as Newcastle confirmed with their midweek victory at Chelsea. Alan Pardew's team are trying to get into the Champions League and have a striker, Papiss Cissé, who has equalled the Premier League record of 13 goals in his first 12 games. City's last championship in 1968 was secured at St James' Park, courtesy of a 4-3 victory that helped them pip Manchester United by two points. Now, like then, it could be a defining day. Daniel Taylor

QPR's fortunes took a distinct turn for the worse with last Sunday's 6-1 humiliation at Stamford Bridge, but other results ensured they remain in control of their own destiny. However, with a last-day visit to Manchester City to come, this match feels like win or bust. While Mark Hughes would greatly enjoy possibly denying his former employers the title next weekend, he knows how hard that will be. Beating a tired Stoke on Sunday could be sufficient to keep Rangers up, and they welcome Adel Taarabt back from suspension. Paul Chronnell

These teams will be playing for different types of pride this weekend. Everton can open up a six-point gap over local rivals Liverpool, while Wolves – who are already relegated – can secure their first win under Terry Connor's leadership. Connor will make a late decision on whether Matt Jarvis (groin) and Kevin Foley (hamstring) are fit to play. Moyes is hopeful Leighton Baines will return for the final game of 2011-12 but he will sit out this weekend's match, along with Victor Anichebe, while Jack Rodwell is out until next season. Tom Lutz

This is not a game loaded with intrigue, with the Premier League fate of both teams already decided. For Chelsea, the most important aspect is ensuring there are no untimely injuries with less than a week to go before the Champions League final against Bayern Munich. Roberto Di Matteo will select as few first-team dependables as possible. There will be no return for David Luiz or Gary Cahill, who are yet to recover from their hamstring injuries. A sixth-place finish is Chelsea's worst for a decade, but that barely touches the disillusionment at relegated Blackburn. Amy Lawrence

Newcastle have defied expectation all season and a finale in keeping with their outstanding campaign could yet deliver Champions League qualification. Alan Pardew's team must beat Everton, who have lost at home only twice in 2012, and hope Arsenal or Tottenham slip up, to finish in the top four. Third is also achievable should north London falter spectacularly. Everton have only a parochial battle with Liverpool to play for but are unbeaten in eight games and will want to show David Moyes there is hope as he prepares to consider his future this summer. Andy Hunter

This is shaping up to be the best day of Manchester City's modern history. A win will all but guarantee their first title since 1968 and it is difficult to see them losing their way given this is a contest between the team with the best home record in the league against the side with the least away points. City's biggest opponent might be anxiety but Roberto Mancini's team are a solid bunch, which means fourth-from-bottom QPR may have to rely on Stoke avoiding defeat against Bolton to avoid dropping into the relegation places. A lot is being made about Mancini and Mark Hughes renewing hostilities but, for both managers, there are greater issues at stake. Daniel Taylor

While there is nothing tangible to play for on Sunday – Norwich are safely ensconced in mid-table and Aston Villa have finally limped clear of danger – both teams will be keen to end the season on a high. Paul Lambert has called for his side to put on a good display at Carrow Road after back-to-back home defeats because "too many come to watch us (not to perform)", while Alex McLeish must be feeling the pressure after a dire first full season at Villa. Lambert has admitted he will have to "box clever" this summer as transfer funds are limited but at least he has the luxury of knowing his job is safe. Rich Flower

While the latest twist in this season's relegation tale seemed to inflict huge misery on Bolton, their sacrificing of a 2-0 lead against West Bromwich Albion while QPR found a late winner against Stoke last Sunday has not actually proved fatal. The mission for Bolton remains simple – a win on Sunday will keep them up, unless QPR poop Manchester City's title party. But winning at the Britannia Stadium is far easier said than done, and Owen Coyle has fitness concerns over the midfield trio Mark Davies, Nigel Reo-Coker and Darren Pratley. Paul Chronnell

If Manchester United still contain some romance despite the materialism of the owners, they will picture themselves as champions against the odds. That outcome is unlikely but they must seek a win at Sunderland and hope, in particular, to take an early lead that puts strain on Manchester City, who top the table solely on goal difference. At least Sir Alex Ferguson's side has easily the best away record in the Premier League this season, having won 12 times on their travels and taken a total of 39 points from a possible 54. Kevin McCarra

Defeat in the FA Cup final to Chelsea would appear to have rendered Kenny Dalglish's first full season in charge a failure, no matter how hard he tries to convince everybody otherwise. At a club that has won 18 titles and five European Cups, the Carling Cup and eighth place doesn't quite cut it, as Dalglish well knows. There are many who would like to see a younger, more modern manager at Anfield, someone not unlike Swansea's Brendan Rodgers, who will hope to end a hugely satisfying season with another big scalp on Sunday. Paul Chronnell

Martin Jol will make his first managerial return to White Hart Lane since he was sacked by Tottenham in October 2007 and his chances of exacting vengeance on his former club will be hampered by the absence of top scorer Clint Dempsey with a groin problem. Home manager Harry Redknapp has problems of his own to contend with, though, and he may be forced to play William Gallas out of position at left-back as Benoît Assou-Ekotto has a shoulder injury and Danny Rose is suspended after his sending-off at Aston Villa last week. Rich Flower

Only victory on Sunday will guarantee Arsenal extend their Champions League presence for a 15th successive season, and a four-game winless run has set nerves jangling at the Emirates. Wenger will hope to have Theo Walcott back on the substitutes' bench at least, but will have to rely on Francis Coquelin at right-back in place of broken leg victim Bacary Sagna. The way Albion hit back from 2-0 behind at Bolton last Sunday suggests that, rather than being in party mode, they are determined Roy Hodgson goes out on a high. Paul Chronnell

For most of the season this fixture looked as if it would be a Premier League game in name only, where two long since relegated clubs would bid farewell to the top flight. Wolves did their bit and were down by mid-April, but by then Wigan were beating Manchester United and Arsenal and thrashing Newcastle to hit 40 points with a game to spare. Wolves' incoming manager, Stale Solbakken, will be expected to make major changes this summer, while Wigan will be hoping that this game is not a farewell to Roberto Martínez. Paul Chronnell
